data.name: Introduction
entries: Dungeons & Dragons is a cooperative game in which players create exciting fantasy stories guided by a Dungeon Master, or DM. Imagination and chance determine the fate of the players' characters.

entries.name: An Ongoing Game
entries: Each time you gather to play D&D, you're playing a single game session. These sessions connect to form adventures like the ones in this product. The next time you play, the story picks up where you left off.

entries.name: Choose Your Role
entries: To play D&D with {@i Stranger Things: Welcome to the Hellfire Club}, you need two to five people to play as characters and one person to be the Dungeon Master.

entries.name: Playing a Character
entries: If you want to be one of the protagonists in your group's adventures, consider playing a character. Your character is your alter ego in the fantasy world of the game. Here's what these players do.

entries.name: Choose a Character
entries: Select from the following five characters from the world of {@i Stranger Things}:

items: {@b Lady Applejack}. Played by Erica Sinclair, Lady Applejack is a Chaotic Good, Elf Rogue who will sneak behind any monster, stab them in the back with her kukri, and smile as she watches them die a slow, agonizing death.
{@b Nog the Dwarf}. Dustin Henderson's sturdy Cleric, Nog, has gotten his companions out of a bind more times than he can count. Nog is a devotee of Heironeous, a god of chivalry, justice, and war.
{@b Sundar the Bold}. A gallant and unyielding warrior, Sundar the Bold bravely defends his companions—just like this Fighter's player, Lucas Sinclair.

{@b Tayr the Paladin}. When Mike Wheeler isn't behind the DM screen in his parents' basement, he dusts off his trusty Paladin, Tayr. The heart of the party, Tayr unites his companions and leads the charge in their fight against evil.
{@b Will the Wise}. Will Byer's Wizard is a mainstay of the party and is always up for another adventure. When Will the Wise casts a spell, his magic sometimes manifests in unexpected colors.

entries.name: Team Up
entries: Your character joins the other players' characters to form an adventuring party, often referred to as "the party." These adventurers are allies who face challenges and fantastical situations together. Each character has distinctive capabilities that complement those of the other characters.

entries.name: Venture Forth
entries: Your character's group explores locations and events presented by the DM. You can respond to them however you can imagine, guided by the rules in the {@link D&D Beyond Basic Rules|https://www.dndbeyond.com/sources/dnd/br-2024}. Although the DM controls all the monsters you encounter, the DM isn't your adversary. The DM guides your party's journey as your characters become more powerful.

entries.name: Being the Dungeon Master
entries: If you want to be the mastermind of the game, consider being the DM. Here's what DMs do:

items.name: Run the Adventure
items.entry: You run one or more of the adventures.

items.name: Guide the Story
items.entry: You narrate much of the action during play, describing locations and creatures that the adventurers face. The players decide what their characters do as they navigate hazards and choose what to explore. Then you use a combination of imagination and the game's rules to determine the results of the adventurers' decisions.

items.name: Adjudicate the Rules
items.entry: You oversee how the group uses the game's rules, making sure the rules serve the group's fun. You'll want to read the {@link D&D Beyond Basic Rules|https://www.dndbeyond.com/sources/dnd/br-2024}, and you'll find the {@book rules glossary|XPHB|10} essential.

entries: {@comic Don't worry, Henderson. I'm not going to leave you high and dry. Papa Bear is here. I've left notes like this throughout the adventures to give you a peek behind the scenes and help you run these adventures, but you gotta make 'em your own. You can do this. {@b I believe in you.}}

entries.name: Swapping Roles
entries: Playing a character and being the Dungeon Master aren't permanent roles. Each adventure is a self-contained story. Whenever you begin an adventure, determine who will be the DM for that story.

If your group consists of five or fewer players, the previous DM can either choose from the remaining characters or play as the new DM's old character. For groups of six, the previous DM always inherits the available character. Either way, ensure that the character's level is appropriate for the upcoming adventure. The adventures span levels 1–3.

entries.name: Getting Started
entries: Once you've chosen the DM, follow the instructions below to begin play.

entries.name: If You're Playing a Character
entries: Follow these steps to prepare your character:

items: {@b Choose a Character}. Pick one of the five level 1 Characters from {@adventure appendix D|WttHC|8}.
{@b Review Your Character}. Take a moment to look over your Character Sheet. When you're ready, introduce your character to the other players.

entries.name: If You're the Dungeon Master
entries: Follow these steps if you're the DM:

items: {@b Review the {@i D&D Beyond Basic Rules}.} Familiarize yourself with the {@link D&D Beyond Basic Rules|https://www.dndbeyond.com/sources/dnd/br-2024}. You don't need to memorize every rule before you play, but you should understand the rhythm of play and where to find relevant information when needed.

{@b Prepare the First Adventure}. "The Vanishing Gnome" is designed for level 1 characters. Read the {@area Key Plot Points|012|x} and {@area Adventure Background|016|x} sections. These sections present important context for the adventure, though the story that ultimately emerges is the one your group experiences.

entries: Now you're ready to play D&D. Hell yeah!

entries.name: Running the Adventures

entries.title: Greyhawkins

entries: The following information is key to running the adventures.

Text that appears in a box like this is meant to be read aloud or paraphrased for the players when their characters first arrive at a location or under a specific circumstance, as described in the text.
When a monster's name appears in Bold type, that's a visual cue to say, "Hey, DM, you should get this stat block ready. You're going to need it."
Magic items are described in Appendix A, while NPCs and Monsters are described in Appendix B.

data.name: The Vanishing Gnome
entries: {@i An Adventure for Level 1 Characters}
This adventure is designed to fill one or two sessions of play.
If you aren't using the {@adventure Map of Greyhawkins|WttHC|0|Running the Adventures}, it can take place in any shadowy dungeon.

entries.name: Key Plot Points
entries: This information is key to the adventure's story:

items.name: Plot Point 1
items.entry: {@creature Flizzlebin|WttHC} magically contacts the characters and challenges them to find him in the {@area Dungeon of Shadows|01b|x}.

items.name: Plot Point 2
items.entry: The characters navigate the Dungeon of Shadows in search of Flizzlebin, who calls out to them from his {@adventure hiding place|WttHC|1|Flizzlebin's Hiding Spot} in a twisted reflection of the dungeon connected to a mysterious realm known as the Vale of Shadows.

items.name: Plot Point 3
items.entry: A spawn of Demogorgon, a demon lord, has escaped the Vale of Shadows. The characters first encounter the creature in the Dungeon of Shadows, but it likely escapes.

items.name: Plot Point 4
items.entry: After defeating the {@creature Demogorgon Spawn|WttHC}, the characters find Flizzlebin and earn the gnome's reward.

entries.name: DM Preparation
entries: Before running the adventure, prepare as follows:

items.name: Step 1
items.entry: Read the "{@area Adventure Background|016|x}" section.

items.name: Step 2
items.entry: Read the "{@area Hide-and-Seek|017|x}" section and secretly note Flizzlebin's hiding spot.

entries: {@comic Don't let anyone from Hawkins PD catch you with this. Officer Callahan still thinks I stole all those lawn gnomes that went missing a few years back. Consider this booklet evidence.}

items.name: Step 3
items.entry: Familiarize yourself with the creatures in this adventure, which are as follows:

items.name: Step 4
items.entry: Familiarize yourself with the magic items in this adventure, which are as follows:

entries.name: Player Assistance
entries: You can simplify the DM's role by having the a player handle tasks typically assigned to the DM. Before play begins, see if a player would like to be the {@b Rules Consultant}. That player references the {@link D&D Beyond Basic Rules|https://www.dndbeyond.com/sources/dnd/br-2024} as needed.

entries.name: Adventure Background
entries: {@creature Flizzlebin|WttHC}, the Vanishing Gnome, tests the mettle of would-be heroes in dangerous games of hide-and-seek in dungeons throughout the land. Over the years, the elusive gnome has magically contacted countless travelers, but few have accepted his quests—and fewer have completed them. Successful seekers have emerged from these dungeons with priceless treasures and pockets brimming with gold.

Recently, Flizzlebin vanished to the Dungeon of Shadows, a maze that borders a gloomy, monster-infested realm. There, his calls to adventurers awakened a foul creature: a spawn of the demon lord Demogorgon! As Flizzlebin eagerly broadcasts his quest, the ravenous demon stalks the dungeon, complicating the gnome's game and endangering all who seek him.

entries.name: Hide-and-Seek
entries: Flizzlebin hides in the Shadow Dungeon, a mirror of the Dungeon of Shadows. Roll on the Flizzlebin's Hiding Spot table to determine where the characters can find the gnome in the dungeon (detailed later in this adventure). Flizzlebin avoids harm in his hiding place by using his {@item Cap of Vanishing|WttHC}.

entries.caption: Flizzlebin's Hiding Spot
rows: Chamber of Bad Choices ({@area area S1|044|x})
Wasteland of Filthy Vines ({@area area S2|048|x})

entries.name: Beginning the Adventure
entries: When the players are ready to begin the adventure, read or paraphrase the following text:
You travel a well-trod road through craggy and forested country. As you pass a dense thicket, a voice calls out to you exuberantly.

"Well-met, adventurers! 'Tis I, Flizzlebin, the Vanishing Gnome, the illustrious vagabond, the emissary of evasion! I have sequestered myself deep within the fabled Dungeon of Shadows, where I wait with a magical reward for those who prove themselves worthy. Find me, and the treasure is yours. Travel east to find the dungeon's entrance. Beware! Horrid creatures lurk within the dungeon's darkest corners... and so do I."
The voice fades. Do you accept this quest?

At your discretion, one or more of the characters might have heard of Flizzlebin from stories shared in taverns throughout the land. If the characters follow the gnome's instructions, they quickly arrive at the Dungeon of Shadows.

{@comic I've run this adventure a bunch of times. Every once in a while, I wind up with a player who has played the damn thing already, and you will, too. My advice? {@b Never run it the same way twice.} Hide Flizzlebin somewhere else. Add a couple of Vine Blights to the Shadow Dungeon. That'll keep everyone on their toes and stop blabbermouths from spoiling the fun for the newbies—and themselves.}

entries.title: A howling stone tunnel marks the entrance to the Dungeon of Shadows

entries.name: Dungeon of Shadows
entries: The Dungeon of Shadows is the bridge between Greyhawkins and the Vale of Shadows, a mirror world in a realm of shadow. Bloodthirsty gnolls, giant arachnids, deadly traps, and worse terrors await visitors to the dungeon.

A warped version of the dungeon is reflected within the Vale of Shadows. Flizzlebin hides within this shadow of the dungeon above, which is accessible only through portals hidden throughout the dungeon.

entries.name: Arriving at the Dungeon
entries: When the characters arrive at the Dungeon of Shadows, read or paraphrase the following text:
You reach the entrance to the Dungeon of Shadows. Black briars grow around the entrance's mouth, which resembles a howling stone face. Past the opening, rough-hewn stairs descend into darkness.
A character can inspect the entrance and make one of the following checks to recall lore about the dungeon and the gloomy realm it borders:

{@b {@dc 12} Intelligence ({@skill History|XPHB}).} Monsters infest this dungeon, which is suffused with shadowy magic. The dungeon was once a temple devoted to a long-forgotten god, and its reputation is as tenebrous as its entrance. Rumors speak of a second, more sinister dungeon connected to this one.

{@b {@dc 12} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}).} The dungeon is magically linked to the Vale of Shadows, a grim reflection of the natural world. Dreadful creatures and living shadows lurk in this dark and twisted reality; occasionally, some of these creatures escape the vale to plague the people of Greyhawkins.

The staircase descends 60 feet to {@adventure area D1|WttHC|1|D1: Chamber of Choice}. When the characters enter the dungeon, use the Dungeon of Shadows Map to see where the characters begin in that area.

{@comic Flizzlebin can speak to the characters whenever you want him to. If your players are really green, he can be the voice of the DM, A.K.A. the voice of reason. He might contact the characters to drop a hint, give words of encouragement... or warn them of {@b CERTAIN DEATH}.}

items.name: DM Secret!
items.entry: The map for this adventure depicts the Dungeon of Shadows and its reflection in the Vale of Shadows. Keep the Vale of Shadows hidden from your players until they enter it, as detailed later in this adventure.

entries.name: Dungeon Features
entries: The dungeon has the following features:

items.name: Ceilings
items.entry: The ceilings are 20 feet high in rooms and 10 feet high in passages.

items.name: Doors and Secret Doors
items.entry: Doors are unlocked and made of basalt. Secret doors manifest as spidery, elastic fissures that blend in with their surroundings. As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character can examine a wall that contains a secret door and make a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check, noticing it on a successful check. A secret door opens as easily as any normal door.

items.name: Lighting
items.entry: Torches in iron wall sconces fill the dungeon with {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB}.

entries.name: Dungeon Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to the Dungeon of Shadows map. The map also indicates where each character begins in the dungeon.

entries.name: D1: Chamber of Choice

entries: This chamber has five stone doors, each bearing a different image and inscription.

The torches in the chamber flicker as a faint, disembodied voice calls to you. "I'm pleased you have accepted my quest," says Flizzlebin. "I am here, but I am not here. Find me, and I shall reward you greatly. Be forewarned! You are not the only creatures who seek me in this accursed place." A monstrous roar echoes throughout the dungeon.

Flizzlebin speaks to the characters from the {@area Shadow Dungeon|03f|x} (detailed later in this adventure). The gnome magically contacts the characters as they explore the dungeon, but he doesn't say anything else to characters in this area unless you decide otherwise. Flizzlebin has discovered that his communications have attracted the spawn of Demogorgon (see {@adventure area D3|WttHC|1|D3: Labyrinth of Doom}), and he doesn't want to further draw its ire.

entries.name: Doors
entries: Each of the five doors is adorned with a relief sculpture and an inscription as follows:

items: Door to {@adventure D2|WttHC|1|D2: Wasteland of Filth} This door bears the image of a fuming urn. The inscription reads "Wasteland of Filth."
Door to {@adventure D3|WttHC|1|D3: Labyrinth of Doom} This door bears a relief of a ferocious, many-horned minotaur above a stone maze. The inscription reads "Labyrinth of Doom."

Door to {@adventure D4|WttHC|1|D4: Forge of Gibbletrax} In this door's relief, three mischievous creatures with pointed ears and sharp teeth surround an anvil. The inscription reads, "Forge of Gibbletrax."
Door to {@adventure D5|WttHC|1|D5: Den of Itsy} A spiderweb is etched into this door. The inscription reads "Den of Itsy."
Door to {@adventure D6|WttHC|1|D6: Altar of Yeenoghu} Etched into this door is the image of a scowling, bipedal hyenoid warrior. The door's inscription reads "Altar of Yeenoghu."

entries.name: D2: Wasteland of Filth

entries: A putrid stench hangs in this room. Gnawed bones, rotten food, and ancient junk litter the stone floor.
This room holds refuse discarded by the dungeon's denizens.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character can sift through the trash and make a {@dc 12} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check. The first character to succeed on the check unearths five ivory urns. Each urn is worth 10 GP. Four of the urns are empty, but one contains a {@item Potion of Healing|XDMG} and a tiny pewter statue of a two-headed demon worth 90 GP. A character who inspects the statue and succeeds on a {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Religion|XPHB}) check recognizes the statue as an idol of the demon lord Demogorgon.

entries.name: D3: Labyrinth of Doom

entries: The torches along the walls of this maze begin to flicker, and a familiar disembodied voice says, "Many adventurers have met their demise in these corridors. Beware the fearsome minotaur!"

entries.title: A spawn of Demogorgon feeds on its latest victim

entries: Until recently, a bloodthirsty minotaur ruled this trap-filled labyrinth. However, an even more vicious creature—the spawn of Demogorgon, a demon lord—escaped the Vale of Shadows and slew the minotaur. The spawn is devouring the minotaur's corpse in the middle of the labyrinth.

entries.name: Spear Traps
entries: The labyrinth contains three spear traps triggered by pressure plates hidden in the floor, as denoted with a "T" on the Dungeon of Shadows map. Cobwebs and dust obscure the holes that house these spears.
Each spear trap has the following rules:

items.name: Detect and Disarm
items.entry: As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character can examine the walls and make a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check, detecting the holes on a successful check. Alternatively, a character can take the {@action Study|XPHB} action to inspect the floor and make a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check, detecting the pressure plate on a successful check.

items.name: Triggering the Trap
items.entry: When a creature moves onto a trap's pressure plate for the first time on a turn, spears thrust out from the walls. Each creature on the pressure plate must succeed on a {@dc 13} Dexterity Saving Throw or be struck by a spear, taking {@damage 1d6} Piercing damage. The spears then retract, and the trap resets immediately.

entries.name: Terror in the Maze
entries: When the characters reach the center of the maze, read or paraphrase the following text:

The torches in this bloodstained corridor sputter erratically. A thin, sinewy creature with slimy, gray skin and elongated limbs crouches over a slain minotaur. The corpse squelches and snaps unsettlingly as the creature gorges on it. A small chest lies beside the mangled minotaur.

The {@creature Demogorgon Spawn|WttHC} continues devouring the minotaur for 1 minute or until it detects the characters. The spawn is {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward all other creatures.
{@comic This encounter is pretty tough. Go easy on them... unless they're being ********, in which case you should give 'em hell.}

To sneak past the spawn while it feeds, a character must succeed on a {@dc 13} Dexterity ({@skill Stealth|XPHB}) check. On a failed check, or if the characters otherwise disturb the spawn, it turns toward the adventurers. When that happens, read or paraphrase the following text:
The creature turns toward you, and its faceless head peels back to reveal five toothed, fleshy petals around a gaping mouth. It screeches and rushes toward you.
Roll Initiative!

The Demogorgon spawn fights until it is reduced to 25 Hit Points or fewer, at which point it retreats through the secret door to {@area area S3|04b|x} of the Shadow Dungeon (detailed later in this adventure). If the characters manage to defeat the Demogorgon spawn here, the adventure doesn't end; the characters still must find Flizzlebin to complete his quest.
If the characters don't disturb the spawn and aren't detected, the creature finishes its meal and then relocates to {@area area S4|050|x} in the Shadow Dungeon.

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: A secret door (see "{@area Dungeon Features|042|x}") is set into the wall in the southeast corner of the labyrinth. It leads to {@area area S3|04b|x}. Characters who witnessed the Demogorgon spawn use this secret door automatically succeed on checks to find the door.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The chest in the middle of the labyrinth contains a {@item Wand of Secrets|XDMG} and 25 GP.

entries.name: D4: Forge of Gibbletrax

entries: Clanging hammers ring out in this sweltering chamber. Three goblin smiths cluster around a glowing forge in the center of the room. The goblins sing in scratchy tones as they work:
{@i "Deep within the Dungeon of Shadows},
{@i We strengthen steel to slay the beasts.}
{@i Upside down in the Vale of Shadows},
{@i Brave heroes delve to keep us free."}

Blessed by a long-forgotten god, the Forge of Gibbletrax is a magic forge stewarded by three {@creature Goblin Warrior|WttHC|Goblin Warriors} named Ble, Gib, and Trax. These smiths craft gear to defend against the dungeon's threats.

The goblins are initially {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} toward the characters but defend themselves if necessary. If the characters approach the goblins peacefully, the goblins greet the characters warmly and ask what brings them to the dungeon.

Ble, Glib, and Trax usually keep to themselves, but they recently clashed with the gnolls in {@adventure area D6|WttHC|1|D6: Altar of Yeenoghu}, whose profane rituals threaten the sanctity of the forge. If the characters agree to end the gnolls' foul rites, the goblins vow to imbue the characters' weapons with the forge's magic.

entries.name: Forge of Gibbletrax
entries: The goblins' magical forge can temporarily infuse weapons and ammunition with immense heat. As a Bonus Action, a character can dip one weapon or piece of ammunition into the forge, coating it in a thin layer of molten ore. A creature that takes damage from the ore-coated weapon or ammunition takes an extra {@damage 1d6} Fire damage. Once coated, the weapon retains its heat for 10 minutes or until its damage is dealt, whichever comes first.

A character can benefit from the Forge of Gibbletrax only once, unless the goblins permit them to do so again. If all three goblins are slain or the forge is removed from this area, its magic ceases to function.

entries.title: Three goblin smiths—Ble, Gib, and Trax—gleefully toil away at their magic forge while singing a work song

entries.name: You can do this!
entries: {@comic Sure, these smiths could have been dwarves, but that would've been BORING. Anyone can be a smith, just like anyone can be a Dungeon Master.}

entries.name: D5: Den of Itsy

entries: Thick, sticky webs cover this once-regal chamber. Skeletons encased in cocoons hang from webs on the ceiling as grim warnings to all who enter.

A cobwebbed statue of an eight-foot-tall, armor-clad knight presides over the chamber. Before it is a stone pedestal, atop which rests a shimmering crystal spider roughly five feet in diameter. A fiery greatsword burns within the crystal spider's body, casting a warm, orange glow on the tangled nest.

items.name: DM Secret!
items.entry: Don't reveal the {@creature Giant Spider|WttHC} yet. This monster is hiding.

entries: This room is the nest of Itsy, a {@creature Giant Spider|WttHC} that preys on any who enter its lair. The {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} spider clings to the ceiling, guarding the secret door and treasure in this room (detailed below). If a character opens the secret door or disturbs the crystal spider, Itsy begins combat.

entries.name: Crystal Spider
entries: The crystal spider is a Medium object with AC 13, HP 50, Resistance to Piercing and Slashing damage, and Immunity to Poison and Psychic damage. Destroying the crystal spider frees the treasure inside (detailed below).

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: Set into the east wall of this room is a secret door (see "{@area Dungeon Features|042|x}") that connects to {@area area S5|054|x}.

entries.name: Statue
entries: The statue depicts a knight in a gallant pose. As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character can examine the statue and make a {@dc 12} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check. On a successful check, the character realizes the statue's base is unstable; a significant push could topple the statue.

As an action, a character within 5 feet of the statue can make a {@dc 10} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check to topple the statue into a space within 5 feet of it, doing so on a successful check. When the statue topples, each creature beneath it takes {@damage 4d6} Bludgeoning damage and has the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition. The statue crumbles on impact, revealing a treasure hidden inside it (see "Treasure" below).

entries.name: Webs
entries: The web-filled areas are {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}.

A creature that enters a web-filled area for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there must succeed on a {@dc 12} Dexterity Saving Throw or have the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition. As an action, a creature Restrained by the webs can try to escape from them, doing so with a successful {@dc 12} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) or Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics|XPHB}) check.
Each 5-foot {@variantrule Cube [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Cube} of webs has AC 10; HP 7; Vulnerability to Fire damage; and Immunity to Piercing, Poison, and Psychic damage.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Inside the statue is a heart-shaped emerald worth 30 GP. The sword encased in the crystal spider is a {@item Flame Tongue Greatsword|XDMG| Flame Tongue (Greatsword)}.

entries.name: D6: Altar of Yeenoghu

entries: In this square chamber, three hyenoid warriors kneel before an altar bearing a wicked-looking flail. Two of the creatures cackle maniacally as the third—the mangiest of the three who's nearly devoid of hair—chants, "Yeenoghu! Hear our laughter and let there be bloodshed and butchery!" The flail glows with sickly light.

These three {@creature Gnoll Warrior|WttHC|Gnoll Warriors} worship Yeenoghu, a merciless demon lord who delights in slaughter. The {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} gnolls fight all other creatures on sight.

entries.name: Completing the Ritual
entries: If the characters don't interrupt the gnolls, they continue their ritual. After 1 minute, booming laughter erupts from the altar. Any creatures other than the gnolls in this area must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw, taking {@damage 1d8} Thunder damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.

After the ritual, the gnolls leave to battle the goblins in {@adventure area D4|WttHC|1|D4: Forge of Gibbletrax}. If the characters don't intervene, the gnolls overpower the goblins, and the Forge of Gibbletrax loses its magic forever.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The flail on the altar is a {@item +1 Flail|XDMG}.

entries.name: Shadow Dungeon
entries: Beneath the Dungeon of Shadows lies the Shadow Dungeon, a gloomy reflection of the dungeon that borders the Vale of Shadows. Though its chambers mirror the areas above, their contents differ, distorted by the eerie realm they border.

entries.name: Finding Flizzlebin
entries: To find Flizzlebin, the characters must defeat the Demogorgon spawn and any {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} creatures in Flizzlebin's hiding spot (see the "{@area Hide-and-Seek|017|x}" section earlier in this adventure). When both conditions are met, the gnome appears to the characters; proceed to this adventure's conclusion.
If the characters reach Flizzlebin's hiding spot before they vanquish the Demogorgon spawn, read or paraphrase the following text:
"Ah! You found my hiding spot! But your work isn't done yet," says a familiar voice. "To claim your prize, you must slay the horrid creature that hunts me."
Flizzlebin doesn't bequeath his reward until the characters comply with his instructions. At your discretion, he might reveal the Demogorgon spawn's location—likely {@area area S4|050|x}.

entries.name: Shadow Dungeon Features
entries: The Shadow Dungeon has the following features:

items.name: Ceilings
items.entry: The ceilings are 20 feet high in rooms and 10 feet high in passages.

items.name: Lighting
items.entry: The dungeon is unlit. Area descriptions assume the characters have a light source or other means of seeing in {@variantrule Darkness|XPHB}. Bare iron sconces line the walls.

items.name: Doors and Secret Doors
items.entry: Doors are unlocked and made of basalt. Secret doors manifest as spidery, elastic fissures that blend in with their surroundings and exude faint rays of natural light when opened. As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character can examine a wall that contains a secret door and make a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check, noticing it on a successful check.

entries.name: Shadow Dungeon Locations
entries: The characters can enter and leave the Shadow Dungeon through the secret door that connects {@adventure areas D3|WttHC|1|D3: Labyrinth of Doom} and {@area S3|04b|x} or the secret door that connects {@adventure areas D5|WttHC|1|D5: Den of Itsy} and {@area S5|054|x}. The following locations are keyed to the upside-down portion of the Dungeon of Shadows map.

entries.name: S1: Chamber of Bad Choices

entries: This eerie chamber has five stone doors, each bearing a vile image and inscription. A dead dwarf is slumped in a shadowy corner. The corpse clutches a torn sheet of parchment in its stiff hand. Near the dwarf, a stone staircase blocked by rubble ascends into darkness.

This room mirrors the Chamber of Choice ({@adventure area D1|WttHC|1|D1: Chamber of Choice}). The corpse is that of a dwarf explorer who perished four days ago while searching for Flizzlebin. The dwarf was killed by an Undead shadow.

The dwarf's body is unnaturally thin, and its clothes look too big. A character can inspect the corpse and make a {@dc 12} Wisdom ({@skill Medicine|XPHB}) check. On a successful check, the character discerns the dwarf's life was sapped by a supernatural force.

The dwarf clutches a note. If the characters remove it from the corpse, show the players the Dungeon Warning Handout. After the characters read the note, a {@creature Shadow|WttHC} rises from the dwarf's corpse and begins combat.

entries.title: {@5etoolsImg Dungeon Warning Handout|pdf/WttHC/000-warning-note.pdf}

entries.name: Doors
entries: Each of the five doors is adorned with a relief sculpture and an inscription as follows:

items: Door to {@area S2|048|x} (Urn). This door bears the image of an urn wrapped in ink-black vines. The inscription reads "Wasteland of Filthy Vines."
Door to {@area S3|04b|x} (Labyrinth). This door's relief depicts a fungal maze. The inscription reads, "Labyrinth of Gloom."
Door to {@area S4|050|x} (Spiked Anvil). In this door's relief, a shadowy figure looms over a spiked anvil. The inscription reads, "Forge of Annihilation."
Door to {@area S5|054|x} (Web). A black spiderweb is etched into this door. The inscription reads "Den of Bitsy."
Door to {@area S6|05a|x} (Hand and Eye). A desiccated hand holding an eye decorates this door. Deep scratches make the inscription illegible.

entries.name: Staircase
entries: The staircase, blocked by rubble, leads to the Vale of Shadows. That realm and its contents are beyond the scope of this adventure, but you can flesh them out as you see fit. Otherwise, the staircase is impassible.

entries.name: S2: Wasteland of Filthy Vines

entries: Slithering black vines squirm along the floor of this trash-filled room.
This room mirrors the Wasteland of Filth ({@adventure area D2|WttHC|1|D2: Wasteland of Filth}). The floor is {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The first character to sift through the trash and succeed on a {@dc 12} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check unearths five cracked urns hewn from black granite. The urns are worthless. Four of the urns are empty, but one contains a {@item Potion of Healing|XDMG} and a glass eye with an emerald pupil worth 10 GP.

entries.name: S3: Labyrinth of Gloom

entries: Clouds of spores drift throughout this stone labyrinth. The maze is overgrown with fungi and foot-tall mushrooms that sprout from the walls and floor.

This stone maze mirrors the Labyrinth of Doom ({@adventure area D3|WttHC|1|D3: Labyrinth of Doom}). The maze is home to toxic plants and four {@creature Shrieker Fungus|WttHC|Shrieker Fungi}. Two {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} {@creature Myconid Adult|WttHC|Myconid Adults} also roam the maze, fighting any non-Plants they encounter.
If the shriekers sound off, the myconids investigate the disturbance. The shriekers don't shriek if the myconids come within 30 feet of them.

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: A secret door (see "{@area Shadow Dungeon Features|042|x}") is set into the wall near the southeast corner of the maze. It leads to {@adventure area D3|WttHC|1|D3: Labyrinth of Doom}.

entries.name: Spore Traps
entries: The labyrinth contains three spore traps—swollen plant bulbs that exhale puffs of toxic spores—triggered by stepping on pressure plates of inflated mushrooms. These traps are marked on Dungeon of Shadows map with a "T." The fungus-infested walls obscure the bulbs that spray these spores.
Each spore trap has the following rules:

items.name: Detect and Disarm
items.entry: As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character can examine the walls and make a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Nature|XPHB}) check, identifying the toxic bulbs on a successful check. Alternatively, a character can take the Study action to inspect the floor and make a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check, identifying the fungal pressure plate on a successful check. Trimming the stems that connect the bulbs to the pressure plate prevents the trap from triggering.

items.name: Triggering the Trap
items.entry: When a creature moves onto a pressure plate for the first time on a turn, the bulbs spray toxic spores that fill a 5-foot {@variantrule Cube [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Cube} centered on the pressure plate. Each creature in the Cube must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution Saving Throw or have the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition for 1 hour. The trap resets immediately.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A dilapidated chest in the middle of the labyrinth contains a broken wand and 25 GP. The wand is useless.

entries.name: S4: Forge of Annihilation

entries: An unholy forge dominates this grim chamber. Caustic fumes waft from its icy hearth, which swirls with a faintly glowing, pale-green slurry. Skulls bob along the liquid's surface.

This room mirrors the Forge of Gibbletrax ({@adventure area D4|WttHC|1|D4: Forge of Gibbletrax}). If the {@creature Demogorgon spawn|WttHC} survived its previous encounter with the characters (see {@adventure area D3|WttHC|1|D3: Labyrinth of Doom}), it lurks here. Read or paraphrase the following text:
A familiar, horrible creature—the same creature you encountered in the labyrinth above—rises from the shadow of the forge. It unfurls its faceless head once more and chitters in anticipation.
Roll Initiative!
The {@creature Demogorgon Spawn|WttHC} fights to the death.

entries.name: Forge of Annihilation
entries: Unlike the goblins' blessed forge in the dungeon above, this forge is a cursed apparatus capable only of destruction. The Forge of Annihilation causes living creatures to wither and die. As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character can inspect the forge and make a {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) check. On a successful check, the character identifies the eldritch hazard and the threat it poses.

A creature that enters the forge for the first time or starts its turn there must make a {@dc 15} Constitution Saving Throw, taking {@damage 4d8} Necrotic damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.title: The Forge of Annihilation—a sinister reflection of the Forge of Gibbletrax—looms within the Shadow Dungeon

entries.name: S5: Den of Bitsy

entries: A statue of an eight-foot-tall knight with a horned, crimson helm stands in this chamber, which is covered in thick, black webs. Atop an altar in the center of the room, a massive spider with dripping fangs wraps a dead elf in webs.
Humanoid-shaped cocoons—the arachnid's ghastly larder—hang throughout the chamber.
This room mirrors the Den of Itsy ({@adventure area D5|WttHC|1|D5: Den of Itsy}). It belongs to Bitsy, an equally territorial {@creature Giant Spider|WttHC}. Bitsy fights the characters on sight.

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: Set into the east wall in this room is a secret door (see "{@area Shadow Dungeon Features|042|x}") that connects to {@adventure area D5|WttHC|1|D5: Den of Itsy}.

entries.name: Statue
entries: The statue depicts a knight with a menacing helm. As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character can examine the statue and make a {@dc 12} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check. On a successful check, the character realizes the statue's base is unstable; a significant push could topple the statue.

As an action, a character within 5 feet of the statue can make a {@dc 10} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check to topple the statue into a space within 5 feet of it, doing so on a successful check. When the statue topples, each creature beneath it takes {@damage 4d6} Bludgeoning damage and has the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition. The statue crumbles on impact, revealing treasure within (see "Treasure" below), but its helm remains intact.

entries.name: Webs
entries: The web-filled areas are {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}.

A creature that enters a web-filled area for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there must succeed on a {@dc 12} Dexterity Saving Throw or have the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition. As an action, a creature Restrained by the webs can try to escape from them, doing so with a successful {@dc 12} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) or Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics|XPHB}) check.
Each 5-foot {@variantrule Cube [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Cube} of webs has AC 10; HP 7; Vulnerability to Fire damage; and Immunity to Piercing, Poison, and Psychic damage.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The statue's helmet is a crimson {@item Dread Helm|WttHC} that resembles the head of a horned devil. Inside the statue is a heart-shaped black tourmaline worth 30 GP.

entries.name: S6: Altar of Vecna

entries: Low fog pervades this eerily quiet chamber. A stone altar rises from the center of the floor. Atop the altar, a dismembered hand grasps an hourglass half-filled with black sand and adorned with bone spindles. The sand defies gravity, flowing to the top bulb.
This room mirrors the Altar of Yeenoghu ({@adventure area D6|WttHC|1|D6: Altar of Yeenoghu}), but this altar honors evil of a viler caliber.

The first character to inspect the hourglass hears the sound of a ticking clock, followed by a baleful chime. The hourglass then cracks, and the sand spills out, revealing a mummified eye within the lower bulb. No other character hears the sound.

Afterward, a character can examine the altar's contents and make a {@dc 12} Intelligence ({@skill Religion|XPHB}) check. On a successful check, the character recognizes the hand and the eye as the symbol of Vecna, a powerful lich feared throughout Greyhawkins. The hourglass is a ceremonial object used by members of Vecna's cult to symbolize the lich's dreaded—and inevitable—return.

entries.name: Conclusion
entries: After the characters defeat the Demogorgon spawn and locate {@creature Flizzlebin|WttHC}, the gnome rewards them. Read or paraphrase the following:
A bearded gnome in a fancy cap addresses you enthusiastically. "Bravery, majesty, and teamwork!" he exclaims. "How wonderful it was to guide you on your quest." He removes his cap.
"For your heroism, I bestow on you my magic cap. But know this: The real treasures were the bonds you formed along the way.
"Go forth! Many great adventures await you."

For their efforts, Flizzlebin gives the characters his {@item Cap of Vanishing|WttHC}. If one of the characters didn't find a magic item during the adventure, the gnome presents the cap to that character.

Flizzlebin is {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} and willing to speak to the characters. During conversation, he fondly recalls the characters' deeds and commends them on their creativity, heroism, or any other qualities you deem appropriate. He then wishes them farewell and vanishes once more, disappearing to a faraway dungeon to challenge a new group of adventurers.

entries.name: Character Advancement
entries: After the characters receive Flizzlebin's reward, everyone in the party gains 1 level. Direct each player to record any treasure they found over the course of this adventure.
{@comic You can bring back Flizzlebin the next time you want to send the characters to a dungeon or reward a player with an item they've been pestering you about. Mike is the worst with this.}
{@comic "Eddie! When are we going to level up?"}
{@comic "Eddie! When do I get a Vorpal Sword?"}
{@comic Obnoxious. Make him work for it.}

data.name: Scream of the Crop
entries: {@i An Adventure for Level 2 Characters}
This adventure is designed to fill one or two sessions of play.
If you aren't using the {@adventure Map of Greyhawkins|WttHC|0|Running the Adventures}, it can take place near any agrarian settlement.

entries.name: Key Plot Points
entries: This information is key to the adventure's story:

items.name: Plot Point 1
items.entry: Rillard Senior, a local farmer, hires the characters to find his missing granddaughter, {@creature Rilly June|WttHC}, and investigate a string of unusual events around his farm.

items.name: Plot Point 2
items.entry: During their search, the characters stumble on a network of tunnels beneath Rillard Family Farm.

items.name: Plot Point 3
items.entry: The characters follow the tunnels to the source of the trouble: a Gulthias tree, a wicked sapling spawned from the stake of a slain vampire. Along the way, the characters confront subterranean monsters and living plants corrupted by the Gulthias tree.

items.name: Plot Point 4
items.entry: The characters find Rilly June and destroy the Gulthias tree and the demonic hounds that guard it.

entries.name: DM Preparation
entries: Before running the adventure, prepare as follows:

items.name: Step 1
items.entry: Read the "{@area Adventure Background|064|x}" section.

items.name: Step 2
items.entry: Familiarize yourself with the {@area Missing Person Poster Handout|138|x} and the {@area Farm Tunnels Map|06e|x}.

items.name: Step 3
items.entry: Familiarize yourself with the creatures in this adventure, which are as follows:

items.name: Step 4
items.entry: Familiarize yourself with the magic items in this adventure, which are as follows:

items: {@item Potion of Acid Resistance|XDMG|Potion of Resistance (Acid)}

entries.name: Player Assistance
entries: You can simplify the DM's role by having the other players handle tasks typically assigned to the DM. Before play begins, work with the other players to divide the following tasks among them:

items.name: Monster Wranglers
items.entry: Whenever the characters encounter {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} monsters, one or two players can run these monsters using the referenced stat blocks.

items.name: Rules Consultant
items.entry: One player references the {@link D&D Beyond Basic Rules|https://www.dndbeyond.com/sources/dnd/br-2024} as needed.

entries.name: Adventure Background
entries: In decades past, the vampire Gunthar the Gluttonous terrorized the people of Goldenwheat. Gunthar and his three faithful hounds threatened to drink the farmers and their livestock dry. When all hope seemed lost, a group of brave heroes slew Gunthar in his crypt and plunged a stake into his heart. They left the crypt victorious, sealing the crypt behind them and leaving a stake buried in the vampire's corpse.

Over time, the blood-soaked stake warped and sprouted a Gulthias tree, a plant infused with evil essence. Malignance spreads from this tree, destroying crops, corrupting soil, and spawning awakened plants with a taste for blood. The tree's evil was contained for a time within Gunthar's crypt, and farms flourished in a land the vampire had filled with despair—until now.

An ankheg hungry for local livestock recently tunneled into Gunthar's crypt. The Gulthias tree's roots reached into the ankheg's tunnels, infecting them with blights and fungi and spoiling the crops above. The tree's vile tendrils even worked their way into the corpses of Gunthar's hounds. Returned to life and mutated by the tree, these bloodthirsty dogs loyally guard their master's resting place and destroy any who threaten the Gulthias tree.

A local farmer has reached out to the characters, hoping they can put an end to the blight affecting his crops and those of other nearby farms. If the disease continues to spread, the ensuing food shortage could prove disastrous.

entries.title: Rillard Senior, a halfling farmer, looks out at his blight-ridden farm

entries.name: Beginning the Adventure
entries: The bucolic hills of Goldenwheat hold fields of corn, seas of grain, and patches of plump pumpkins. Located along a prominent trail in southern Greyhawkins, these fertile farms regularly supply the region with bountiful harvests. At least one farm, however, has been struggling recently.

A brutal blight has struck Rillard Family Farm. For years, Rillard Senior, his granddaughter, and their hired hands have been a reliable source of wheat, producing hundreds of bushels each fall. If the blight isn't dealt with soon, some towns might go without bread this winter.
The adventure begins in Goldenwheat and assumes the characters have already accepted this heroic undertaking. Read or paraphrase the following text to begin the adventure:

As you crest the hill into Goldenwheat, a pathetic sight greets you: a barren stretch of wilted gray stalks, collapsed gourds, and cracked earth. A stale breeze sweeps over the farms, carrying the stench of decay.

Near the road, a sad-looking scarecrow slumps on its stand, its rotting pumpkin head hung low and swarming with flies. Ahead, a wooden sign swings from a crooked post. It reads "Rillard Family Farm." Further up the road, a small farmhouse sits among the barren fields.
If the characters disturb the scarecrow, it falls apart. Otherwise, when a character next looks toward it, the scarecrow has mysteriously vanished.

{@comic Foreshadowing is one of the most important skills in your DM toolbox, but players can throw you for a loop. The scarecrow the characters pass here is supposed to be the one they encounter later in the tunnels beneath the farm, but if they **** with it, you'll have to pretend that was a totally different scarecrow. Hint at the scarecrow along the road without making it seem too interesting or important. Then wait for the juicy reveal.}

entries.name: Arriving at Rillard Family Farm
entries: Rillard Family Farm grows crops and raises livestock as part of the Goldenwheat farming collective. When the characters arrive at the farmhouse, read or paraphrase the following text:
The Rillard farmhouse is a humble two-story home with a wraparound porch. An elderly halfling wearing a straw hat sits in a rocking chair on the porch, staring at the blighted fields.
The chair creaks as the halfling rises slowly. He looks you over while scratching his bushy sideburns and nods. "Well met," he says.

"Y'all look like a band of capable folks. I'm Rillard Senior, but you can call me Ol' Rill. I hate to admit it, but my farm and my family are in a heap of trouble. I'm hoping y'all can help us out. These old bones ain't made for adventuring."

Rillard (Small, Neutral Good {@creature Commoner|WttHC}) is a lifelong farmer who periodically hires adventurers to help around his farm and ward off varmints. He is {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} toward the characters and treats them with respect. After a brief introduction, Rillard explains that strange happenings have befallen his farm. He shares the following details:

items.name: Blighted Crops
items.entry: The crops on the farm are dying, even after magical intervention by a traveling mage. Rillard doesn't know the blight's cause.

items.name: Missing Person
items.entry: Rillard's granddaughter, Rilly June, is missing. Rillard says she's a tough cookie who can hold her own even after a hard day's work on the farm, but he's starting to worry. He hasn't seen her in two days.

items.name: Stolen Scarecrows
items.entry: Meddlesome whippersnappers have been stealing Rillard's scarecrows, each of which has a pumpkin for a head. If the characters mention they saw one along the road (see "{@area Beginning the Adventure|065|x}"), Rillard remarks that one of his scarecrows was plucked from that very spot a few days ago, but he hadn't replaced it yet. He jokes that the scarecrow might have "up and run off on its own."

items.name: Vanishing Livestock
items.entry: Someone has been poaching Rillard's heifers. He locks the barn every night, but one cow disappears every other night.

entries.name: Rillard's Request
entries: Rillard asks the characters to find his granddaughter and investigate the unusual events around his farm. He offers them 200 GP to find Rilly June and unearth the source of the blight.

If the characters accept, Rillard provides them with a sketch of Rilly June that he was planning to give to the authorities. Show your players the Missing Person Poster. Rillard also loans the party his great granddaddy's {@item Poison Soaked Kukri|WttHC|Poison-Soaked Kukri}, hoping it will aid them in their exploration.

entries.name: Story Time
entries: If the characters accept Rillard's quest, he thanks them kindly and says they remind him of the brave heroes who saved these lands long ago. Rillard then briefly recounts the story of the vampire Gunthar the Gluttonous (as detailed in this adventure's background), though he knows nothing of the ankheg tunnels or the Gulthias tree beneath his farm.

Rillard adds that some say Gunthar cursed these farmlands with his last breath, while others say the vampire haunts these lands still. The old farmer believes the story is simply used to scare young children so they return home before nightfall.

entries.name: Exploring the Farm
entries: The characters can investigate any of the events Rillard observed, each of which leads them to one of the tunnels beneath the farm (detailed in the following section). Rillard can point them in the right direction as follows:

items.name: Blighted Crops
items.entry: If the characters go into the fields to investigate the crops, they stumble on a tunnel entrance hidden behind a rotten bale of wheat. The tunnel slopes down to {@area area T1|071|x}.

items.name: Missing Person
items.entry: If the characters search the farmhouse for clues to Rilly June's whereabouts, they happen on several loose floorboards in the basement that, when pried up, reveal an earthen tunnel. The tunnel descends to {@area area T6|081|x}.

items.name: Stolen Scarecrow
items.entry: If the characters return to where they last saw the scarecrow, they quickly find a trail of straw that leads to a hole in the ground. It leads to {@area area T3|075|x}.

items.name: Vanishing Livestock
items.entry: If the characters explore the barn, they find a hole beneath a partially collapsed hay pile. It leads to {@area area T4|07a|x}.

entries: {@comic Listen, I get it. Everyone wants to adopt a friendly NPC to tag along on a quest—hell, devious players even use them as dungeon cannon fodder. Point is, this is where you can put your foot down, and say, {@b "Nope, Ol' Rill ain't goin' with you."} He's like eighty years old.}

entries.name: Farm Tunnels
entries: Beneath Rillard Family Farm lies a network of tunnels dug by a ravenous ankheg. The ankheg inadvertently burrowed into the sealed crypt of Gunthar the Gluttonous, unleashing the roots of the Gulthias tree that grows there. The tree's roots have spread rapidly from the dead vampire's resting place, overtaking the tunnels and releasing a rash of blights to wreak havoc on the surrounding farms.

When the characters enter the tunnels, the Player Characters' starting location on the Farm Tunnels Map is based on which event they investigated (see "{@area Exploring the Farm|06c|x}"). Don't reveal the locations of the tunnels' other contents at the outset, as they aren't yet visible to the characters.

entries.name: Tunnel Features
entries: Unless otherwise noted, the tunnels have the following features:

items.name: Ceilings
items.entry: The ceilings are 10 feet high.

items.name: Lighting
items.entry: The tunnels are unlit. Creatures rely on {@sense Darkvision|XPHB}, {@sense Blindsight|XPHB}, or {@sense Tremorsense|XPHB} to see. Area descriptions assume the characters have a light source or other means of seeing in {@variantrule Darkness|XPHB}.

items.name: Roots and Vines
items.entry: Writhing, ink-black roots and vines pervade the tunnels. Areas covered in roots (as denoted on the map) are {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}. As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character can inspect the plants and make a {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) check; a successful check reveals the vegetation is corrupted by a malevolent supernatural force.

entries.name: Tunnel Locations

entries.title: Tunnels covered in the Gulthias tree's invasive roots wind beneath Rillard Family Farm

entries: The following locations are keyed to the Farm Tunnels Map. That map also shows the locations of characters and monsters in the tunnels.

entries.name: T1: Entrance Tunnel

entries: A thin mist rises from a dirt tunnel. Writhing black vines cling to the earthen walls. A distant, bone-chilling howl echoes from the depths.

The howl originated in Gunthar's crypt ({@area area T9|08e|x}), where the late vampire's monstrous hounds reside. A character who hears the howl and succeeds on a {@dc 13} Wisdom ({@skill Nature|XPHB}) check knows that no ordinary dog or wolf can produce such a sound.
The tunnel exits to a field on Rillard Family Farm.

entries.name: T2: Fungus-Infested Tunnel

entries: Two plants shaped like droplets with purple lattice-like branches sprout from the ground in this tunnel. Their tendrils snake toward the ceiling and intertwine with vines that cover every surface.

items.name: DM Secret!
items.entry: Don't reveal the location of the {@creature Vine Blight Tangler|WttHC|Vine Blight Tanglers} yet. These monsters are hiding. At the start of combat, any character who didn't notice these blights has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on their Initiative roll.

entries: The purple plants are two {@creature Violet Fungus|WttHC|Violet Fungi}. Two Vine Blight Tanglers hide among the Gulthias roots. As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character can survey the area and make a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check, detecting the blights on a successful check. The fungi and blights are {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward all non-Plant creatures. If such a creature comes within 10 feet of the plants or otherwise disturbs them, they enter combat.

entries.name: T3: Spore-Filled Tunnel

entries: Tiny white spores drift through the air in this musty tunnel. Black vines creep up to the ceiling, where a shiny pendant hangs from a gnarled root, glinting innocently.
Scarecrows stand silently throughout the chamber. Each has a rotten pumpkin for a head.

items.name: DM Secret!
items.entry: Don't reveal the {@creature Scarecrow|WttHC} yet. This monster is hiding. At the start of combat, any character who didn't notice the scarecrow has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on their Initiative roll.

entries: Though most of the scarecrows in this tunnel are inanimate, one of them is a {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} Scarecrow. It remains motionless, hoping to ambush the characters. As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character can inspect the scarecrows and make a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check. On a successful check, the character recognizes the living scarecrow hiding among the inanimate ones.
If the characters disturb the pendant or the scarecrow, the scarecrow begins combat, surprising any characters who didn't identify it as a threat.

entries.name: Stalking Scarecrow
entries: If the characters don't fight the scarecrow in this area, it follows them after they leave this tunnel. It strikes when the characters are most vulnerable, such as immediately after combat with the ankheg (see {@area area T5|07e|x}).
At your discretion, if the characters later return to this area, one or more scarecrows might be missing, suggesting that others might be hunting them.

entries.name: Toxic Spores
entries: A cloud of toxic spores fills this area. When a creature enters the area, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or have the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition for 1 minute. A creature that fails the save repeats it at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. A creature that succeeds on its save is immune to the effect of these spores for 24 hours.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The pendant that hangs from the ceiling is a {@item Periapt of Health|XDMG}.

entries.name: T4: Ankheg's Nest

entries: The floor of this spacious chamber is ten feet lower than that of the three tunnels that branch from it. A horrid stench rises from the floor, where decaying cow carcasses and bovine bones twitch under a network of slowly constricting, otherworldly roots.

items.name: DM Secret!
items.entry: Don't reveal the {@creature Needle Blight|WttHC|Needle Blights} yet. These monsters are hiding. At the start of combat, any character who didn't notice these blights has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on their Initiative roll.

entries: The ceilings in this chamber are 20 feet high. The tunnels that lead into this area end abruptly in a 10-foot drop. Along the sunken floor, wicked roots curl around the remains of the ankheg's meals.

Three Needle Blights hide among the roots and carcasses. As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character can examine the floor and make a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check, detecting the blights on a successful check. The blights are {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward the characters. If the characters step on the roots or disturb the carcasses, the blights begin combat.

entries.name: Carcasses
entries: As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character can inspect the dead livestock and make a {@dc 13} Wisdom ({@skill Medicine|XPHB}) check. On a successful check, the character discerns that the cows were violently slain and dragged here by a hulking creature with acidic mandibles.
A character who inspects the carcasses can make a {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) check. If the check succeeds, the character realizes that this area is an ankheg's nest.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Amid the carcasses is a burlap sack that contains a loaf of two-day-old bread, three apples, 5 GP, and a {@item Potion of Acid Resistance|XDMG|Potion of Resistance} (Acid). The sack has the initials "R.J." stitched on it.

entries.name: T5: Foggy Chamber

entries: Thick fog fills this damp chamber, which smells of freshly dug dirt. Low, chitinous clacking noises echo within the obscuring mist, accompanied by the sounds of shifting earth and clattering rocks.

items.name: DM Secret!
items.entry: The ankheg has {@sense Tremorsense|XPHB}, which means it has no trouble finding its way through the fog or noticing the characters when they approach.

entries: An {@creature Ankheg|WttHC} is using its mandibles to slowly widen this chamber. It is {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward all other creatures and starts combat once it detects them.

entries.name: Fog
entries: This tunnel is {@variantrule Heavily Obscured|XPHB} by fog.

entries.name: T6: Boneyard

entries: Luminescent particles float throughout this chamber. Bones litter the earthen floor. Slithering roots worm their way over the graveyard and slowly deconstruct a skeleton clad in shredded leather armor.

The particles gather around the dead warrior, twinkling as an echoing, disembodied voice calls to you. "Who goes there? Are you adventurers? I have been stuck here for an awfully long time. Can you free me?"

items.name: DM Secret!
items.entry: Don't reveal the {@creature Vine Blight Tangler|WttHC} yet. These monsters are part of the Gulthias Tree's roots and manifest only if those roots are attacked.

entries: {@comic They go for the treasure {@b every time} I run this one. I thought the scarecrow was supposed to be the one who's missing a brain!}

The disembodied voice is that of Justine Fobarb, a human adventurer slain long ago. Her spirit is trapped within her entangled remains. Justine doesn't have a Monster Stat Block and can't be targeted by any attack, spell, or other effect. She is initially {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} toward the characters, promising to share her story once freed.

The Gulthias tree's evil roots tether Justine's spirit to this area. A character who inspects the roots and succeeds on a {@dc 12} Intelligence ({@skill Religion|XPHB}) check realizes that by destroying the roots, they can set Justine free.

entries.name: Destroying the Roots
entries: The Gulthias roots have AC 10; HP 15; and Immunity to Bludgeoning, Piercing, and Psychic damage. If the roots take damage, read or paraphrase the following text:
The roots squeal and writhe in pain. "Look out!" cries the disembodied voice. The vines along the tunnel walls begin to peel away and curl into two bipedal figures that rush toward you.
Roll Initiative!

entries.title: Two blights emerge from a root-tangled wall to deal with intruders

entries: The two {@creature Vine Blight Tangler|WttHC|Vine Blight Tanglers} fight the characters.
If the roots are destroyed, Justine's spirit passes to the afterlife, but not before warning the characters of the dangers that lurk within these tunnels.

entries.name: What Justine Knows
entries: If the characters free Justine's spirit, her attitude improves to {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly}, and she shares the following information:

items.name: Ankheg
items.entry: A big, acid-spitting bug roams these tunnels. It preys on the cattle above and drags them to its nest ({@area area T4|07a|x}).

items.name: Demodogs
items.entry: The vampire Gunthar had three bloodthirsty hounds. Long after they met their end, they've returned as doglike monsters that guard Gunthar's final resting place ({@area area T9|08e|x}).

items.name: Gulthias Tree
items.entry: A Gulthias tree is an accursed plant that might sprout from the blood-soaked stake of a slain vampire. Justine believes such a tree grows in Gunthar's crypt ({@area area T9|08e|x}) and is the source of the blight that poisons this land. Fire can weaken a Gulthias tree, but the only way to truly destroy this evil is to uproot it completely.

items.name: Vampire
items.entry: The vampire legends are true. Long ago, Justine's adventuring party hunted down Gunthar and drove a stake through his heart. But Justine was slain by one of Gunthar's minions, and her fellow party members abandoned her in their quest for glory. Justine's spirit lingered, vainly hoping they would return; eventually, the roots became her cage.

entries.name: Never split the party, kids.
entries: {@comic What kind of despicable adventurers would abandon a fellow party member when they needed them most? Poor Justine.}
After Justine shares what she knows, the twinkling motes fade, and silence falls over the tunnel once more.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: After destroying the roots, a character can inspect Justine's remains. Around her skeleton's neck hangs a silver emblem of Heironeous, a god of chivalry, honor, and justice. The emblem is shaped like a lightning bolt and is worth 25 GP.

entries.name: T7: Vine-Covered Tunnel

entries: The tunnel walls disappear behind a mass of snaking black vines. Two bipedal creatures covered in thorns stand between you and the next bend. The spiny guardians take turns scratching their bristling hides with a rusty rake. Farming tools are scattered across the ground.

items.name: DM Secret!
items.entry: Don't reveal the {@creature Vine Blight Tangler|WttHC} yet. These monsters are hiding. At the start of combat, any character who didn't notice these blights has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on their Initiative roll.

entries: Two {@creature Needle Blight|WttHC|Needle Blights} use a stolen rake to scratch each other's backs in this tunnel. Two {@creature Vine Blight Tangler|WttHC|Vine Blight Tanglers} hide among the vines along the walls, waiting to ambush any non-Plant creatures that pass through this area. The blights are {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward the characters.

As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character can scan the vine-covered walls and make a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check. On a successful check, the character spots the Vine Blight Tanglers.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Among the rusty farming tools are a pair of gardening gloves, a hoe, a shovel, and an heirloom ring worth 10 GP.

entries.name: T8: Crypt Antechamber

entries: You stand before the entrance to a buried crypt. Thick vines cover its crumbling stone doors, and gnarled black roots weave across the chamber floor. Near the doors, the vines wrap around a halfling farmhand. She's out cold.

The adventurers who defeated Gunthar sealed the doors to his crypt ({@area area T9|08e|x}). When the ankheg began burrowing beneath Rillard Family Farm, it demolished the doors, unleashing the Gulthias tree and the blight it brings.

entries.title: The Gulthias tree's roots restrain Rilly June

entries: The farmhand is {@creature Rilly June|WttHC}, Rillard's granddaughter, whom the characters can easily identify thanks to the sketch her grandfather provided. Rilly June has the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} and {@condition Unconscious|XPHB} conditions, but she is otherwise unharmed.

{@b Freeing Rilly June}. As an action, a character can make a {@dc 15} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check to free Rilly June from the vines, doing so on a successful check. Once freed, Rilly June wakes up and introduces herself. She is {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} toward the characters, and can share the following information:

items.name: Tunnel
items.entry: Rilly June heard digging sounds in the farmhouse basement, where she found a tunnel. She followed the tunnel, hoping it might reveal clues about the blighted crops, but she was ambushed by strange creatures and brought here.

items.name: Unusual Tree
items.entry: Rilly June caught a peek at the crypt ({@area area T9|08e|x}). Somehow, there's a tree growing underground there.

items.name: You Have My Pitchfork!
items.entry: Rilly June volunteers to accompany the characters as they confront the source of the blight. Her farm is in peril, so she has a right to help defend it.

entries: A character can try to convince Rilly June to return to the surface by using an {@action Influence|XPHB} action to make a {@dc 15} Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) check. On a successful check, Rilly June begrudgingly returns to the safety of the farmhouse. Otherwise, she accompanies the characters for the rest of this adventure.

entries.name: T9: Gunthar's Crypt

entries: A black-barked tree looms crookedly over this eerie crypt. The tree's gnarled branches press against the fifteen-foot-high ceiling, and its twisted trunk rises from the splintered lid of a closed coffin encaged in knotted roots. Squirming vines wriggle along the crypt's walls.
Three hideous dogs with eyeless faces growl as they pace around the tree.

This crypt once belonged to Gunthar the Gluttonous. The tree that protrudes from Gunthar's coffin is a Gulthias tree, sprouted from the stake plunged into the vampire's chest. Though the vampire is long vanquished, the tree's magic resurrected his three loyal hounds and transformed them into Demodogs. The Demodogs are {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward all non-Plant creatures and defend their master's remains.

images.title: Transformed by the magic of the Gulthias tree, Gunthar's three wretched hounds guard the vampire's remains

entries.name: Gulthias Tree
entries: This Gulthias tree is a Huge object that has AC 15; HP 50; Immunity to Necrotic, Poison, and Psychic damage; and Vulnerability to Fire damage. If the tree is reduced to 0 Hit Points, read or paraphrase the following text:
The tree screeches as it withers and dies. Silence falls over the crypt, but the tree remains defiantly in place, its roots anchored deep into the earth.

Unless the Gulthias tree is uprooted, it regrows in {@dice 3d10} days. As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character can examine the tree and make a {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) check. On a successful check, the character knows the Gulthias tree will regrow if left in the earth.

To uproot the tree, a character must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check. If Rilly June is with the characters, she takes the {@action Help|XPHB} action to assist them with this endeavor.

If the tree is uprooted, its effects end immediately, and all remaining {@creature Needle Blight|WttHC|Needle Blights} and {@creature Vine Blight Tangler|WttHC|Vine Blight Tanglers} within the tunnels die.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: After uprooting the Gulthias tree, the characters can access the contents of Gunthar's wrecked coffin. Inside are the vampire's desiccated corpse and the following items:

items: A {@item +1 Dart|XDMG} in the shape of a strange pollywog
An amulet sporting a delicate crystal spider, which is worth 25 GP
A blue silk handkerchief with gold embroidery, which is worth 5 GP

entries: Fearing these items were cursed, the adventurers who slew Gunthar refused to take them.

entries.name: Conclusion
entries: When the characters return to the farmhouse, Rillard awaits them on the front porch. How he greets them depends on whether his granddaughter made it home safely.
If the characters rescued Rilly June from the tunnels beneath the farm, Rillard is elated to see them. Read or paraphrase the following text:
As you approach the farmhouse, Rillard leaps from his rocking chair. "Well yank my sideburns and call me cornbread. It turns out real heroes do still exist!" he exclaims.
Rillard tips his hat. "You have done my family and this farm an immeasurable kindness. Why don't y'all come on in and rest a while? I've got pumpkin soup on the stove. You've earned it."

{@comic If Rilly June accompanies the characters on their quest to end the blight, you can either run Rilly June yourself or give her Stat Block to another player. NPCs like her are a great way to deliver in-world hints or lore. {@b Try not to get them killed.}}

Rillard invites the characters to stay the night and enjoy a home-cooked meal. He pays them before they set out on their next adventure. Rilly June and her grandfather invite the characters to revisit the farm any time, providing free, comfortable lodgings and a hot meal whenever the characters stop in.
If the characters return without Rilly June, read or paraphrase the following text:
As you approach the farmhouse, you spot Rillard in the same old rocking chair. He hasn't moved since you left.
Rillard hangs his head in disappointment. "Alone, I see," he mutters. "I guess heroes just ain't what they used to be."

If Rilly June met her end in the tunnels beneath the farm, Rillard's reward is the same, but he pays the characters solemnly and doesn't invite them to stay. Otherwise, Rillard urges the characters to return to the tunnels and rescue his granddaughter.

entries.name: Rillard's Reward
entries: Rillard pays the characters 200 GP as promised. He also lets the characters keep his great grandaddy's {@item Poison Soaked Kukri|WttHC|Poison-Soaked Kukri}.

entries.name: Character Advancement
entries: After the characters receive Rillard's reward, everyone in the party gains 1 level. Direct each player to record any treasure they found over the course of this adventure.

{@comic Reward players who think outside of the box. It's called the {@b Rule of Cool}, a.k.a. the {@b Don't-Be-A-Square Rule}. Take the Gulthias tree, for example. If the characters want to cast a spell to break the roots, conduct a ritual to break the tree's magic, or lure the ankheg into melting it with acid—embrace their creativity! This is {@b your} table now, and you make the rules. Don't let them get in the way of a good time. {@b As long as everyone is having fun, there's no wrong way to play D&D.}}

data.name: Ballad of the Rat King
entries: {@i An Adventure for Level 3 Characters}
This adventure is designed to fill one or two sessions of play.
If you aren't using the {@adventure Map of Greyhawkins|WttHC|0|Running the Adventures}, it can take place in any port town.

entries.name: Key Plot Points
entries: This information is key to the adventure's story:

This nautical-themed tavern caters to dockworkers, deck hands, and other dockside regulars. Its two human proprietors are siblings and former sailors, Jay Le'Buck and Jeeves Whalington (Medium, Chaotic Good {@creature Commoner|WttHC|Commoners}). "Captain" Jeeves spends his days daydreaming about adventures at sea and entertaining patrons. His sister, Jay, handles the real work that keeps the business afloat. She tallies the day's sales on a small chalkboard.

items: {@b Plot Point 1}. A guard named {@area Fillius|0a0|x} hires the characters to investigate a string of murders along the docks. The culprit is {@area Korex|09f|x}, an ex-adventurer who commands a growing horde of sewer-dwelling rats with his magic pan flute.
{@b Plot Point 2}. Deputized by Fillius as temporary members of the Oakshore Guard, the characters question townsfolk and search the dockside neighborhood for clues.
{@b Plot Point 3}. After reporting their findings to Fillius, the characters set a trap for Korex. They confront Korex when he emerges from the sewers on the night of their investigation.

entries.name: DM Preparation
entries: Before running the adventure, prepare as follows:

items: {@b Step 2}. Familiarize yourself with the {@area Oakshore Docks Map|0a6|x} and the {@area Writ of Authority Handout|139|x}.
{@b Step 4}. Familiarize yourself with the monsters and non-player characters in this adventure, which are as follows:
3 {@creature Swarm of Corrupted Rats|WttHC|Swarms of Corrupted Rats}
{@b Step 5}. Familiarize yourself with the magic items in this adventure, which are as follows:
{@item Potion of Acid Resistance|XDMG|Potion of Resistance (Acid)}

entries: {@comic This adventure is a cautionary tale for players who like to steal from their party members. Let this adventure serve as a warning—you can play whatever kind of character you want, but you {@b must} play nicely with others at the table.}

entries.name: Player Assistance
entries: You can simplify the DM's role by having the other players handle tasks typically assigned to the DM. Before play begins, work with the other players to divide the following tasks among them:

items.name: Monster Wranglers
items.entry: Whenever the characters encounter {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} monsters, one or two players can run those monsters using their linked Stat Blocks. (If you have two players doing this, they can take turns.)

items.name: Rules Consultant
items.entry: One player references the {@book D&D Beyond Basic Rules|XPHB} as needed.

entries.title: Rats and murder plague the grimy streets of Oakshore's dockside neighborhood

entries.name: Adventure Background
entries: Korex the Cunning was once an adventurer and a musician who inspired his companions through song. But Korex greed outweighed his heroism. Every quest became a potential heist, an opportunity for Korex to steal from his fellow adventurers or the folk who sought their aid. Eventually, Korex's treachery was revealed. His betrayed companions ousted him, reclaimed what stolen wealth remained, and set off without him.

Korex remained in Oakshore with nothing but his pan flute. He quickly earned himself the reputation of a washed-up performer who never repaid his debts. Humiliated and penniless, Korex retreated to Oakshore's sewers, where he found company in his only remaining audience: rats.

In his isolation, Korex has learned how to control the rats, infecting them with defiling magic channeled through his pan flute. Enthralled by Korex's pestilent song, the rats swarm the pier at night, preying on all who spurned Korex.

With the captain of the local guard away on official business, her diffident second-in-command turns to the characters for aid, hoping to deputize them as detectives to lead an official investigation.

entries.name: Beginning the Adventure
entries: When the players are ready to begin the adventure, read or paraphrase the following text:

An urgent call for aid has brought you to the quiet port town of Oakshore. When you arrive, the harbor is mostly empty, no doubt due to recent reports of dock workers being slain at night. A stocky dwarf in a guard uniform sits on the curb, groaning and rubbing his temples. He leaps to his feet when he spots you.

"It's about time!" he exclaims. "Captain Skipper is away on business. I didn't know who else to call. Over the past week, three dock workers have been slain in the night. I need you to bring the killer to justice."

The dwarf is the inept second-in-command of Oakshire's local guard, Fillius Kellaghan (Medium, Neutral Good {@creature Guard|WttHC}). Fillius has a nonchalant demeanor and a noticeable lack of gusto. While the captain is away, Fillius can hire adventurers as temporary members of the town guard, whose ranks are already spread thin.
Fillius imparts the following information:

items: {@b Curfew}. Fillius has issued a strict curfew. Locals must remain indoors until the case is solved.
{@b Dead Workers}. The victims were discovered at the end of their shifts. All their bodies were riddled with tiny holes. Fillius had the bodies burned as a precautionary measure.
{@b Trade Stoppage}. Fillius closed the docks, halting trade. Oakshore can't afford the closure for long.

entries: Fillius offers the party 200 GP to gather evidence related to these crimes, plus an additional 100 GP if the characters apprehend or eliminate whoever or whatever is responsible for these grisly acts.

entries.name: Honorary Investigators
entries: If the characters accept the assignment, Fillius deputizes them as temporary members of the Oakshore Guard in a brief and underwhelming curbside ceremony.

entries.name: Authority of Oakshore
