entries: To aid the characters in their investigation, Fillius provides them with a document that authorizes them to question locals, enter any location along the dockside neighborhood, and, if necessary, use force to protect the townsfolk. Show the {@area Oakshore Writ of Authority|139|x} to the players when they are deputized.
Fillius also provides the characters one of his two {@item Speaking Stones|WttHC} and tells them to contact him with the stone when they're ready to present their findings.

entries.name: Conducting the Investigation
entries: The characters are free to conduct the investigation however they see fit. Fillius can offer the following suggestions for ways to gather clues:

items: {@b Entering Locations}. The characters have permission to enter any of the dock's locations, although they might have to present the writ of authority to convince an occupant to permit them entry.
{@b Looking for Clues}. The characters can search the docks for physical evidence related to the dock workers' deaths.
{@b Questioning Witnesses}. The characters can talk to the locals.

entries: Fillius cautions the characters not to act brashly and to keep the peace whenever possible. He trusts them to conduct a thorough investigation rooted in sound evidence, integrity, and even tempers.

At your discretion, Fillius might remain nearby to offer additional information or a second opinion to the party during the adventure. Otherwise, he wishes the characters good luck and departs to fill out reports.

{@comic Running a mystery can be hard work. No matter where the characters go, they should always find at least one clue. When the characters talk to the locals, you can suggest questions for them to ask, like these:}

items: {@comic {@b "What did you see on the nights of the murders?"}}
{@comic {@b "Aside from the murders, have you noticed anything unusual or suspicious lately?"}}
{@comic {@b "Who or what do you think is to blame?"}}

entries.name: Oakshore Docks
entries: Normally a bustling hub of business and trade, the Oakshore docks are devoid of activity.

entries.name: Starting the Investigation
entries: Refer to the Oakshore Docks Map and identify the Suggested Start Area for the Player Characters. Don't reveal the rest of the dock's contents yet, as they aren't initially visible to the characters.
To begin the investigation, read or paraphrase:

Oakshore's dockside neighborhood consists of six single-story homes and businesses separated by dingy alleys. Shells in intricate geometrical patterns adorn the facade of each building. Across the cobblestone street, flagstone steps descend to a rickety pier and a gloomy harbor. The neighborhood is eerily still. The only sounds come from the pier, where tides splash against barnacle-laden beams. Where do you want to go first?
Have the players choose a location shown on the map. The characters can visit locations in any order, and they don't have to visit all of them to complete their investigation.

When the characters have enough information to present their findings to Fillius, proceed to "{@area Ending the Investigation|0ca|x}." If you'd like to shorten this adventure, you can have Fillius contact the characters using his {@item Speaking Stones|WttHC|Speaking Stone} after they've explored three or four locations, which should provide them with enough information to make an educated guess about the killer's identity.

entries.name: Oakshore Docks Features
entries: Unless otherwise specified, the docks have the following features:

items: {@b Ceilings}. Ceilings are 10 feet high inside businesses and residences.

{@b Doors}. Doors throughout the docks are made from palm wood planks banded with iron. Unless otherwise noted, doors are unlocked. As a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action, a character can try to pick a locked door using {@item Thieves' Tools|XPHB}; a successful {@dc 15} Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand|XPHB}) check opens it. Alternatively, a character can take an action to try to force open a locked door, doing so with a successful {@dc 15} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check.
{@b Rattraps}. Oakshore's residents have scattered rattraps throughout the docks in response to a sudden rodent infestation.

entries.name: Oakshore Docks Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to map 3. The map also shows you where to place tokens.

entries.name: 01a: Cobbler's Storefront

entries: A boot-shaped wooden sign near the entrance of this shop reads "Suresoles Boots Shoes."

The proprietor of this cobbler's shop is a superstitious dwarf named Nina Suresoles (Medium, Chaotic Good {@creature Commoner|WttHC}). Her passion for finely crafted footwear is matched only by her interest in ghosts and the afterlife.
When the characters enter, read or paraphrase the following text:

The smell of leather fills this warm shop, whose walls are lined with shelves displaying boots and shoes of every size. A young dwarf with thick braids emerges from the back room to greet you. "Customers! Come on in," she says. "I've got boots and shoes for sale; which'll it be?"

Nina is {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} toward the characters and welcomes them into her shop regardless of whether they present the writ of authority. She offers to sell the characters boots or shoes for 1 GP per pair.
If the characters question Nina about the murders, her sunny disposition turns solemn. She asks them to follow her into the workshop ({@area area 01b|0ae|x}).

entries.name: 01b: Cobbler's Workshop

entries: Damaged shoes are piled in the center of this workshop. Cobbler's tools, soles, and leather scraps hang from the walls, and a pristine pair of fancy red boots rests on a workbench.

items.name: DM Secret!
items.entry: Don't reveal the {@creature Swarm of Corrupted Rats|WttHC} yet. These monsters are hiding.

entries: The pile of damaged shoes is 3 feet tall and {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}. Three Swarms of Corrupted Rats hide in the shoe pile. If a character moves within 5 feet of the pile or otherwise disturbs it, the {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} rats erupt from the pile and begin combat. If Nina is present, she shrieks and takes refuge in the storefront ({@area area 01a|0ab|x}); the rats ignore her.

items.name: Questioning Nina
items.entry: Although she speaks in hushed tones, Nina answers all questions honestly and knows the following information:

items: {@b Fancy Boots}. The eye-catching red boots on Nina's workbench in this area were commissioned by an adventurer named Korex as part of a stage outfit. When Korex couldn't pay for the boots, the cobbler kept them. Nina hasn't seen Korex since.

{@b Haunted Shoes}. Nina believes the shoes in her workshop are haunted by the murderer's victims. On the night of each incident, Nina saw the shoes move on their own, cryptically adding that "damaged souls move damaged soles."
{@b Rats}. Rats are a regular sight at the docks, but they've been acting strange lately. Customers have complained about rats gnawing at their shoes, which is why Nina has a heap awaiting repair.
{@b Treasure}. If the characters deal with the rats, Nina gives the characters the boots she made for Korex. The boots are made of red leather encrusted with glitter and are worth 20 GP.

entries.name: 02a: Carpenter's Home
entries: The door to this home is ajar. When the characters approach, read or paraphrase the following text:

A frazzled, grandmotherly gnome peers at you suspiciously from behind the door of this home. An artfully crafted wooden sign above reads "Bibble's Carpentry." The gnome calls out in a shaky voice. "It's not safe out there. Haven't you heard? There's a curfew in place; no one's allowed outside."

The gnome is a carpenter named Bibble Sunspot (Small {@creature Commoner|WttHC}). She is {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} toward the characters and cautiously addresses them from behind the partially opened door. Bibble quickly shuts and locks the door if the characters try to enter her home without her permission.

A character can try to convince Bibble to let them in and make a {@dc 15} Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) check. On a successful check, Bibble's attitude improves to {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly}, and she welcomes them in. On a failed check, Bibble closes and locks the door. If the characters present their writ of authority, Bibble reluctantly invites them into her home.
When the characters enter, read or paraphrase the following text:

The windows in this cozy home are covered with green curtains that block out natural light. Flickering candles illuminate the wood furniture here, all of which is covered in gnaw marks. Muffled screeches frequently erupt from behind a door on the other side of the room.
The few candles leave most of this sitting room in {@variantrule Dim Light|XPHB}.

Bibble crafted all the furniture here. Rats have been chewing on the furniture at night, damaging both priceless heirlooms and pieces for sale. The screeching comes from Bibble's workshop ({@area area 02b|0b3|x}), where she recently trapped a big rat.

items.name: Questioning Bibble
items.entry: If questioned, Bibble becomes nervous and lies. She claims she didn't see or hear anything. A character who doubts Bibble's claims can make a {@dc 12} Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) check; a successful check reveals that she's lying.

entries: As an {@action Influence|XPHB} action, a character can try to pry more information out of Bibble and make a {@dc 12} Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) check. If they saw through Bibble's lie, the check succeeds automatically. On a successful check, Bibble reveals what she knows (detailed below). On a failed check, she refuses to speak to them further and asks them to leave.
Bibble knows the following information:

items.name: Murder Music
items.entry: On the nights of the murders, Bibble heard eerie music coming from the docks. Bibble thinks the music came from a flute.

items.name: Korex
items.entry: The only musician Bibble remembers in Oakshore was a washed-up adventurer who wore out his welcome long ago. He used to perform at the local tavern ({@area area 04|0ba|x}).

items.name: Rats
items.entry: Bibble has seen some big rats in Oakshore, and they sometimes find their way into her home. Last night, she trapped "a real whopper" in her workshop ({@area area 02b|0b3|x}). Bibble offers to pay the characters if they dispose of the rat.

entries.name: 02b: Carpenter's Workshop
entries: The door to this workshop is locked (see "{@area Oakshore Docks Features|0a9|x}"). Bibble carries the key and can unlock the door for the characters. When they enter, read or paraphrase the following:
The screeching stops as you enter this workshop, which contains carpentry tools and unfinished furniture. In the center of the room, a giant, mangy rat gnaws on a hunk of splintered wood.

{@variantrule Dim Light|XPHB} fills the workshop. A {@creature Giant Corrupted Rat|WttHC} has been chewing on in-progress furniture since Bibble trapped it here. The rat is {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward all other creatures.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: If the characters deal with the rat in the workshop, Bibble rewards each character with 1 GP and a stale butterscotch.

entries.name: 03a: Tailor's Storefront

entries: An elegant sign hangs above the door of this humble shop. It reads "Sunderson's Cloaks." Below the sign, a note reads: "Closed until the murders cease—unless you're buying cloaks."

items.name: DM Secret!
items.entry: Although Wexley uses the {@b Cultist of Demogorgon} stat block, represent him on maps using a Commoner token. If his secret is revealed, swap that token for the Cultist of Demogorgon token.

entries.title: Korex's Fancy Stage Boots

entries: The proprietor of this tailor shop is an arrogant elf named Wexley Sunderson. When he isn't secretly worshiping Demogorgon, Prince of Demons, Wexley designs cloaks for Oakshore's well-to-do citizens.
When the characters enter, read or paraphrase:
This sparsely appointed tailor's shop contains a bookcase, textile crates, and cloaks on display. A haughty-looking elf stands amid them, brandishing a large pair of shears. He clears his throat.
"I assume you can read. So, you're here either to kill me or to buy a cloak. Which is it?"

Wexley (Medium, Chaotic Evil {@creature Commoner|WttHC|Commoner (Stranger Things)}) is initially suspicious but {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} toward the characters. If the characters reply that they are here to kill him or if they try to enter his secret room ({@area area 03b|0b8|x}), Wexley becomes {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} and starts combat.

entries.title: A Demobat appears at the completion of an occult ritual in the tailor's secret room

items.name: Secret Door
items.entry: The bookcase is a secret door to {@area area 03b|0b8|x}. As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character can examine the bookshelf and make a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check; a successful check reveals an occult tome, which, if pulled, opens the secret door.

items.name: Questioning Wexley
items.entry: Wexley answers the characters' questions only if they first buy one of his cloaks, which cost 10 GP each. He doesn't respect the writ of authority and laughs if they present it.

entries: Wexley worries the characters might find his secret room. A character who takes the {@action Search|XPHB} action to observe Wexley and succeeds on a {@dc 12} Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) check sees him glance at the bookcase.
Wexley knows the following information:

items.name: Rats
items.entry: An unusual number of customers have needed their clothes repaired lately. The fabric often looks as if it has been chewed by rodents.

items.name: Rumors
items.entry: The local tavern, Pints Ahoy ({@area area 04|0ba|x}), is a good source of juicy gossip.

entries.name: 03b: Tailor's Secret Room
entries: This room is accessed via the bookcase in {@area area 03a|0b5|x}. When the characters enter, read the following:
A wicked symbol is painted on the floor of this secret room. {@creature Cultist of Demogorgon|WttHC|Cultists}' robes and other garments hang on racks along one wall.

As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character can inspect the symbol and make a {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Religion|XPHB}) check; a successful check reveals it to be a ritual circle that cultists of Demogorgon use to summon demons.

If Wexley dies, three {@creature Demobat|WttHC|Demobats} burst from the symbol. The {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} demons appear in three unoccupied spaces nearest the symbol and begin combat when they detect the characters.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A {@item Cloak of Billowing|WttHC} hangs on the wall.

entries.name: 04: Tavern

entries: This miserable-looking establishment has seen better days. A wooden anchor hangs above the door by a single frayed rope. It reads "Pints Ahoy!" Instrumental music plays within.
Even in these trying times, the tavern remains open. When the characters enter, read or paraphrase the following text:

A lively sea chantey fills this ramshackle tavern, whose walls are festooned with nautical decor. A lanky human man with a voluminous pompadour prances about the room, playing an accordion. He wears a sailor's uniform, as does the woman sitting tiredly behind the bar. The tavern is otherwise empty.

"Ahoy, adventurers!" says the frolicking sailor. "Would you like to set sail on an ocean of ale with me? My name is Captain Jeeves Whalington, and I'll be your seafaring guide on this libationary voyage. This is my first mate, Jay Le'Buck. To what sherry shore shall we set sail to first?"

Jay and Jeeves greet the characters warmly and are {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} toward their only customers. If the characters present the writ of authority, Jeeves offers them a free glass of milk or pint of ale (drinker's choice). He insists they call him Captain Whalington.

items.name: Questioning Jay and Jeeves
items.entry: Jeeves welcomes any conversation, including questions about recent events. As the co-owner of the local drinking hole, he knows a little about every dockside resident. Jay chimes in only to correct her brother or deride him with the occasional sarcastic remark.

entries: Jay and Jeeves know the following information:

items: {@b Carpenter}. Bibble Sunspot, the carpenter (see {@area area 02a|0b0|x}), has been acting strange lately. She refuses to let anyone into her home anymore.

{@b Cobbler}. Nina Suresoles, the cobbler (see {@area areas 01a|0ab|x} and {@area 01b|0ae|x}), recently crafted a pair of fantastic boots for Korex, a local musician who used to perform at Pints Ahoy.
{@b Herbalist}. Lampro Capnos, the herbalist (see {@area area 05|0bd|x}), nearly went out of business before the murderers, but they seem to be doing fine now.

{@b Musician}. Jeeves hired Korex to perform in the tavern for a time, but he eventually let Korex go due to the musician's bad manners and poor hygiene. Korex used to live just down the street (see {@area area 07|0c2|x}), but that house has since been abandoned.
{@b Tailor}. Wexley Sunderson, the tailor (see {@area area 03|0b5|x}), has some titillating titles on his bookshelf. Jay thinks the tailor has an embarrassing secret.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: The tavern owners keep 55 GP in an iron lockbox behind the bar. As a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action, a character can try to pick the lock using {@item Thieves' Tools|XPHB}; a successful {@dc 15} Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand|XPHB}) check opens it. Jay carries the key to the lockbox, but both siblings become {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} if they notice a character trying to pilfer their profits.

entries.title: Jay Le'Buck and her brother "Captain" Jeeves Whalington pass the time in their struggling, nautical-themed tavern

entries.name: 05: Herbalist's Shop

entries: The front of this quaint shop is adorned with a bottle-shaped placard that reads "Lampro's Potions." The exterior is overgrown with lush, flowered vines.
The proprietor of this shop is an elf herbalist named Lampro Capnos. When the characters enter, read or paraphrase the following text:

"Customers! Yes, customers!" a soothing voice calls from inside. As the door opens, a smiling elf in a leather apron beckons you into a jungle-like room. An overwhelming odor of strong perfumes mingles with the smell of fresh dirt. A hammock hangs between two potted citrus trees behind a counter brimming with jarred powders, petals, and bulbs.

Lampro (Medium {@creature Commoner|WttHC}) is {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} toward the characters. After introducing themself, Lampro asks whether the characters have come to purchase plants or potions.

The plants that fill the shop range from fragrant floral arrangements to important alchemical ingredients. A character who inspects Lampro's plants and succeeds on a {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Nature|XPHB}) check recognizes that many of them have medicinal properties.

items.name: Potions for Sale
items.entry: In addition to common house plants and floral arrangements, Lampro sells {@item Potion of Healing|XDMG|Potions of Healing} for 50 GP each. The herbalist has {@dice 1d6} vials amid the foliage of a large plant. A character who carefully surveys the shop's interior and succeeds on a {@dc 18} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check notices the potions. Characters who witnessed Lampro retrieve a potion automatically succeed on this check.

items.name: Questioning Lampro
items.entry: Fearing gossip could hurt their struggling business, Lampro answers the party's questions only if a character presents the writ of authority.

entries: Lampro knows the following information:

items: {@b Bad Business}. Even before the murders started, Oakshore's dockside businesses have struggled. Lampro says the cobbler (see {@area area 01a|0ab|x}) was stiffed by a customer who ordered a fancy pair of boots. However, the uptick of crime has resulted in more customers coming to Lampro seeking precautionary {@item Potion of Healing|XDMG|Potions of Healing}. Lampro feels guilty for the boost in sales.

{@b Missing Cat}. Lampro's pet cat, Mr. Whiskers, recently escaped the shop, but due to the curfew, Lampro hasn't been able to look for him. Lampro offers the characters a protective potion if they find Mr. Whiskers. The cat has a bright orange coat and likes to hunt rats in the alley ({@area area 06|0c0|x}).

{@b Musician}. Lampro's old next-door neighbor was a musician and former adventurer. He used to play the most beautiful songs on his pan flute in the evenings, but his house is now abandoned (see {@area areas 07a|0c2|x} and {@area 07b|0c6|x}). Some nights, Lampro swears they can still hear him playing.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: After learning Mr. Whiskers's grisly fate (detailed in {@area area 06|0c0|x}), the characters can report the bad news to Lampro. Alternatively, a character who fabricates a more pleasant outcome for Mr. Whiskers and succeeds on a {@dc 15} Charisma ({@skill Deception|XPHB}) check convinces Lampro that the story is true. Either way, Lampro rewards the characters as promised with a {@item Potion of Acid Resistance|XDMG|Potion of Resistance (Acid)}.

entries.name: 06: Alley

entries: The stones of this dreary alley are flecked with blood. Foul drainage trickles down one side of the alleyway into a sewer grate, while lidded trash cans line the opposite wall. A disgusting squelching noise echoes inside one of the bins.

Inside the largest of the trash cans are two Giant Corrupted Rats feeding on the carcass of Mr. Whiskers, Lampro's missing cat (see {@area area 05|0bd|x}). The rats are {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward the characters but are preoccupied with their meal. If a character opens any of the cans or otherwise disturbs the rats, the rats spring from the container and begin combat.

items.name: Sewer Grate
items.entry: The sewer grate leads to a system of sewers and flood channels under Oakshore. At night, Korex emerges from the grate to terrorize the dockside neighborhood.

entries: The sewers and their contents are beyond the scope of this adventure, but you can flesh them out as you see fit if the characters wish to extend their investigation to the tunnels below.

items.name: Trash Cans
items.entry: The trash cans contain food scraps and other dockside refuse. Inside the largest trash can are the remains of Mr. Whiskers. The characters can identify Mr. Whiskers by the name on his collar, which they can bring to Lampro at the herbalist's shop ({@area area 05|0bd|x}) as proof of the cat's demise.

entries.title: Three dog-sized rats corrupted by Korex's magic feed on a dead pelican while their master is away

entries.name: 07a: Abandoned House Living Area

entries: This house is in shambles. A torn eviction notice is nailed to the front door, whose once-white paint is now yellowed and peeling. The windows are thick with grime, and a foul odor wafts from within.
Korex was evicted from this house after running afoul of his creditors and the people of Oakshore. Although the house appears abandoned, Korex has slowly been moving back into his old quarters.
The front door is locked (see "{@area Oakshore Docks Features|0a9|x}"). Dirty windows obscure the home's interior.
When the characters enter the house, read or paraphrase the following text:
Rat droppings and clumps of mangy fur litter the floor of this sparsely furnished living area, which reeks of sewage. A soiled mattress lies near an old couch, and a battered lute hangs on the wall.

When Korex isn't serenading sewer rats or stalking the docks for his next victim, he hides here, often joined by his rat thralls. The lute on the wall smells like an outhouse and always sounds out of tune.
The rats in {@area area 07b|0c6|x} investigate any loud noises in this area.
{@comic If your players are anything like mine, they might be {@b stupid} and use the Speaking Stone early. If that happens, just have Fillius show up when you need him to.}

entries.name: 07b: Abandoned House Bedroom

entries: A draft flows into this mostly empty bedroom through a broken window. Inside, three monstrous rats gnaw on the remains of a pelican. The rats snarl and growl as they fight over the scraps. Past the rats, a chest sits near the wall.
The three {@creature Giant Corrupted Rat|WttHC|Giant Corrupted Rats} are {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward the characters and fight them on sight.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: Korex stores his spoils in the chest, which contains 75 GP, a gold bracelet worth 30 GP, a silk handkerchief embroidered with silver thread worth 10 GP, and {@item Holly's Handy Haversack|WttHC}.

entries.name: 08: Pier

entries: Waves crash against the pillars of this bloodstained pier. A loading crane looms over a single rowboat bobbing on the water.
The docks rest 5 feet below the street line and are accessible by two flights of stone stairs.

items.name: Boat
items.entry: A single {@vehicle rowboat} is moored at the docks. Inside are a metal pail, a fishing rod, and a burlap satchel that contains moldy cheese and stale bread.

items.name: Crane
items.entry: Affixed to the dock is a sturdy crane fitted with a weighted net. As a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action, a creature within 5 feet of the crane can drop the net on a Medium or smaller creature it can see within 20 feet of the crane. The target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or have the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition until it escapes.

entries: To escape the net, the target or a creature within 5 feet of it must take an action to make a {@dc 10} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check, freeing the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} creature on a successful check. Destroying the net (AC 10; 5 HP; {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to Bludgeoning, Poison, and Psychic damage) also frees the target, ending the effect.

entries.name: Ending the Investigation
entries: The investigation ends when the characters feel they've collected enough information to report to Fillius, who meets them after they contact him with the {@item Speaking Stones|WttHC|Speaking Stone} he gave them.

If the characters correctly deduce that Korex is behind the murders, Fillius agrees that the evidence supports their conclusion. If the characters don't arrive at this discovery themselves, Fillius can help them make the connection. Regardless, Fillius also recounts that Korex is a former adventurer who was ousted for his thievery (as detailed in this adventure's background).

entries.name: Rattrap
entries: Korex will try to strike again. To catch the piper in the act, Fillius recommends the characters set a trap. The characters might confront Korex at any of the following locations:

items: {@b Alley}. Korex emerges from the sewers via the grate in the alley ({@area area 06|0c0|x}). The characters could hide amid the trash cans and ambush him there.
{@b Abandoned House}. If the characters explored Korex's house ({@area areas 07a|0c2|x} and {@area 07b|0c6|x}), they might decide to wait for him there.
{@b Pier}. All the murders happened at the pier ({@area area 08|0c8|x}). The characters could use the crane and its net to catch Korex in the act.

entries: Once the characters agree on a plan and make preparations, allow them to take a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB}, then proceed to the following section.

entries.name: The Rat King Returns
entries: That evening, Korex emerges from the sewer grate in the alley ({@area area 06|0c0|x}), followed by two Swarms of Corrupted Rats. Korex and the swarms are {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward all non-rat creatures. Korex and the swarms then roam the pier ({@area area 08|0c8|x}) before returning to the abandoned house (areas {@area 07a|0c2|x} and {@area 07b|0c6|x}), where they remain for the rest of the night before returning to the sewers.
When the characters confront Korex, read or paraphrase the following text:
A wild-eyed elf wearing a tattered cloak dances down the street, playing a haunting melody on a pan flute. A flood of sickly rats trails behind him, skittering to the beat his tune. The music stops.
"Well, well, well! If it isn't a bunch of goody-goodies come to save the day. Oh well. More food for my rats."
Korex and the swarms fight to the death.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: Korex carries the {@item Pipes of Pestilence|WttHC}.

entries.name: Conclusion
entries: After the characters defeat Korex and his swarms, they can return to Fillius, who commends them on their valiant efforts and keen detective work. Fillius collects the writ of authority and pays the characters 200 GP for the evidence against Korex, as well as an additional 100 GP if they apprehended or dispatched the murderer. As a further token of gratitude, Fillius lets the characters keep both {@item Speaking Stones|WttHC} to aid them in future endeavors.

data.name: Devil, Metal, Die!
entries: {@i An Adventure for Level 3 Characters}
This adventure is designed to fill one or two sessions of play.
If you aren't using the {@adventure Map of Greyhawkins|WttHC|0|Running the Adventures}, it can begin in any tavern before descending into the Nine Hells.

entries.name: Key Plot Points
entries: This information is key to the adventure's story:

items.name: Plot Point 1
items.entry: {@area Dardew|0d5|x} invites the characters to compete in the Hellfire Games. If they accept, they're transported to the {@area Hellfire Dome|0e1|x}.

items.name: Plot Point 2
items.entry: In the Hellfire Dome, the characters face off against devils, demons, and a dragon unlike any other.

items.name: Plot Point 3
items.entry: Spectators shower the characters with gold throughout the competition. If a character falls in battle, Dardew intercedes and offers them the chance to rise and fight again as part of an infernal pact.

items.name: Plot Point 4
items.entry: The characters either complete all the challenges or die trying. Any survivors are inducted into the Hellfire Club.

entries.name: DM Preparation
entries: Before running the adventure, prepare as follows:

items.name: Step 1
items.entry: Read the "{@area Adventure Background|0d4|x}" and {@area "Deal with the Devil|0d6|x}" sections.

items.name: Step 2
items.entry: Familiarize yourself with the {@area Infernal Contract Handout|137|x} and the {@area Hellfire Dome map|0e1|x}.

items.name: Step 3
items.entry: Familiarize yourself with the creatures in this adventure, which are as follows:

items.name: Step 4
items.entry: Familiarize yourself with the Magic Items in this adventure, which are as follows:

entries: {@comic {@b This is it}: the final trial to see who's worthy of joining {@b Hellfire}! This deadly gauntlet separates the wheat from the chaff, real heroes from would-be plunderers. Make sure everyone can make it to game night. If they skip this one, they're {@b OUT}. Lure them with the promise of epic adventure, priceless treasures, and {@b CERTAIN DEATH}.}
{@comic Oh, and snacks. Bring those, too.}

entries.name: Player Assistance
entries: You can simplify the DM's role by having the a player handle tasks typically assigned to the DM. Before play begins, see if a player would like to be the {@b Rules Consultant}. That player references the {@book D&D Beyond Basic Rules|XPHB} as needed.

items.name: Monster Wranglers
items.entry: Whenever the characters encounter {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} monsters, one or two players can run those monsters using the referenced stat blocks. (If you have two players doing this, they can take turns.)

items.name: Rules Consultant
items.entry: One player references the {@book D&D Beyond Basic Rules|XPHB} as needed.

entries.title: Within the Hellfire Dome, {@area Dardew|0d5|x} welcomes an audience of roisterous fiends to the Hellfire Games

entries.name: Adventure Background
entries: From the fires of the Nine Hells rises the infamous {@area Hellfire Dome|0e1|x}, a diabolical arena where contestants of ill repute vie for gold and glory. Death, betrayal, and priceless treasures await those who endure the lethal games in the dome, which are spectated by an audience of disorderly fiends.

Contestants must rely on strength and wits to overcome the diabolical gauntlet that awaits them in the dome. The last and greatest of these trials is a showdown with the {@creature Demodragon|WttHC}: a wretched, two-headed terror created by Demogorgon, the Prince of Demons. Those who slay the Demodragon depart the Nine Hells as wealthy champions.

Winners are also inducted into the Hellfire Club, an exclusive association of infernal origin respected by devils of every rank. Members of the Hellfire Club have a reputation for being tough, fearless, and above all—totally metal.

Every six years, the Hellfire Dome opens its doors to non-Fiends, allowing them to compete in a series of infernal challenges. Dardew the Banished, a cambion with aspirations of grandeur, invites the characters to compete in the arena. If victorious, the characters will be crowned members of the legendary Hellfire Club, and {@creature Dardew|WttHC} will rise in the fiery ranks. However, if the characters lose, they might forfeit their souls.

entries.name: Dardew the Banished
entries: This year's master of ceremonies for the Hellfire Games is a music-loving fiend named Dardew the Banished. A lowly cambion, Dardew hopes to ascend the ranks of the Nine Hells through panache and showmanship, impressing powerful devils in the audience with an unforgettable performance. He believes the characters are his ticket to fame.

entries.name: Deal with the Devil
entries: Few survive the Hellfire Dome in one piece, but those who make deals with devils have a better chance at making it out alive. Early deaths among contestants can make for an underwhelming display, and Dardew can't afford for this year's Hellfire Games to disappoint.

To give the characters an edge in the arena, Dardew has arranged a special contract to keep them fighting beyond the brink of death. Still, no fiend can resist corrupting a mortal soul, especially one that belongs to a good-hearted adventurer. The characters would be wise to consider the contract's fine print before they sign.

{@comic {@b Souls for sale}! Death is a part of the game, but it doesn't have to be the end. And in this adventure, it can be fun for everyone involved! Celebrate players who push their luck and amplify this great, bloody, gladiatorial spectacle. You can always give them their characters' souls back later... {@b if you're a pushover}.}

entries.name: Infernal Contract
entries: Whenever a character drops to 0 Hit Points in the {@area Hellfire Dome|0e1|x}, {@area Dardew|0d5|x} extends an infernal contract to that character. This event takes place outside the Initiative order, which resumes after the character accepts or declines Dardew's offer.
Read or paraphrase the following text:
The scene around you freezes as Dardew appears and unfurls a lengthy contract. "I've got a good feeling about you. How would you like to keep going?"
Show that player the {@area Infernal Contract Handout|137|x} and ask them if their character agrees to the following terms:

items.name: Defying Death
items.entry: When you drop to 0 Hit Points while in the Hellfire Dome—including when you are first offered this contract—you can roll any number of d6s (minimum of {@dice 3d6}) and regain a number of Hit Points equal to the roll's total (no action required). If you roll a 6 on three or more of these dice, you also forfeit your soul and can't benefit from the contract in this way again.

items.name: Forfeiting Your Soul
items.entry: If you forfeit your soul, it becomes the property of Dardew the Banished on your death.

items.name: Voiding the Contract
items.entry: As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, Dardew or an archdevil can void this contract, returning any forfeited souls to their previous owners. Destroying the contract or its arbiter doesn't void the agreement.

entries: If the character accepts these terms, they sign the contract. Dardew then collects the contract and vanishes in a cloud of brimstone. Dardew reappears to offer the same contract to any character who drops to 0 Hit Points while in the Hellfire Dome, even if the character previously rejected the contract.

entries.name: This is Hellfire.
entries: {@comic If the characters reject Dardew, your players are either scaredy cats or a bunch of *****. Either way, put on your favorite mix and wait 'em out. They'll come to their senses eventually.}
{@comic It's D&D or bust.}

entries.name: Beginning the Adventure
entries: When the players are ready to begin the adventure, read or paraphrase the following text:

You sit in an unremarkable tavern somewhere in Greyhawkins when, in a burst of brimstone, a winged, red-skinned fiend with a mane of curly hair and a boyish smile appears. He lands atop one of the tables with an exaggerated bow.
"Greetings, mortal adventurers. My name is Dardew. I hope I'm not interrupting your meal," he says coyly.

"I've come to invite you to compete in the Hellfire Games. I've been watching you for some time now, and I believe you just might have what it takes to join the esteemed Hellfire Club. Care to play the devils' game?"

{@area Dardew|0d5|x} has come to recruit the characters for the Hellfire Games. He is {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} toward the party—but still charming—and shares the following information about the competition:

items.name: Hellfire Games
items.entry: The Hellfire Games are a sexennial competition in which contestants battle for prestige, treasure, and induction into the exclusive Hellfire Club.

items.name: Hellfire Club
items.entry: The Hellfire Club is an invite-only club whose members include epic heroes, high-ranking devils, and figures of legend.

entries: {@area Hellfire Dome|0e1|x}. The games are held in the Hellfire Dome, an arena far from Greyhawkins; Dardew is this year's host and can take the characters there.

If the characters ask about the risk, Dardew explains that while the Hellfire Games are dangerous, the characters have nothing to worry about. He has prepared a special contract to help the characters cheat death (see "{@area Deal with the Devil|0d6|x}"), though he doesn't delve into specifics.

entries.name: Accepting the Invitation
entries: If the characters accept Dardew's invitation, he magically transports them to the Hellfire Dome. Read or paraphrase the following text:
"That's the spirit!" Dardew laughs and claps his hands, and a cloud of red smoke engulfs you.
The characters begin the games in {@area area H1|0e4|x} of the Hellfire Dome.

entries.name: Declining the Invitation
entries: If the characters decline, read or paraphrase:
"Hmm, not what I expected. Oh, well! Maybe next time." Dardew shrugs and disappears with a puff of smoke.
At your discretion, Dardew might return later to reissue his invitation, perhaps offering an important insight or piece of information in return for the characters' participation.

entries.name: Hellfire Dome
entries: Devils prize competition, treachery, and power, so they created the Hellfire Dome, a gauntlet of deadly scenarios designed to feature all three. These challenges take place in a volcanic pit on Avernus, the first layer of the Nine Hells. Just outside the arid dome lies an endless wasteland razed in the Blood War, an eternal conflict between devils and demons.

The Hellfire Dome is a multistory arena hewn from obsidian. A massive dome forged from infernal steel covers the arena, shielding it from meteors that fall from Avernus's skies. Beneath the dome, an infernal steel cage prevents contestants from escaping.

Thousands of devils gather to watch the Hellfire Games. These rowdy onlookers sometimes cast coins into the pit, showering contenders with gold. Unpopular contestants occasionally receive a ball of flame hurled by a disgruntled fiend.

Refer to the {@area Hellfire Dome map|0e1|x} and note that the players begin in the center of {@area area H1|0e4|x}. Don't reveal the rest of the map's contents yet, as it is not not initially visible to the characters.

entries.name: Hellfire Dome Features
entries: The Hellfire Dome has the following features:

items.name: Ambiance
items.entry: The arena is dry and oppressively hot, and it reeks of blood and brimstone. The audience roars with cheers and howls.

items.name: Ceilings
items.entry: Aside from the dome over the arena, the Hellfire Dome has no ceilings. An indestructible cage 60 feet above the pit separates contestants from the audience.

items.name: Lighting
items.entry: Unless otherwise specified, areas in the dome are in {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB}.

items.name: Portals
items.entry: Each of the lettered portals on Hellfire Dome map is a gateway of harmless fire linked to another area in the arena. A creature that enters a portal emerges within 5 feet of the portal with the matching letter on Hellfire Dome map or in the nearest unoccupied space.

entries.name: Dungeon Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to the Hellfire Dome map. The map also shows the locations of characters and monsters in the tunnels.

entries.name: H1: Hellfire Arena

entries: As the smoke clears, you find yourself in a pit within a hellish arena. The temperature is oppressively hot, and the air stinks of sulfur. Thousands of devils leer down at you from rows of seating above a twisted cage of infernal steel. Diabolical music fills the arena.
You stand on a raised platform inscribed with a pentagram. Red flames burn in five braziers, one at each of the star's points.

{@area Dardew|0d5|x} flies over the pit. His voice booms out, quieting the din. "Welcome, one and all, to the Hellfire Dome! Prepare yourselves for a night of death, betrayal, and vile spectacle." The audience erupts in thunderous applause.

"I present to you our latest contenders: group five hundred twenty-seven! Will they survive to become the Hellfire Club's newest initiates? Only time will tell, but we wish them luck. Let the Hellfire Games begin!"
Suddenly, five eyeless, flying demons burst from the fiery braziers.

The five {@creature Demobat|WttHC|Demobats} fight to the death. Whenever the characters vanquish a Demobat, the audience rewards them (see "Treasure" below). Once the characters defeat the bats, five blazing portals appear along the arena's walls.

{@b Dardew} then floats down and congratulates the characters on completing their first challenge. He informs them that only after they have completed at least two more challenges can they proceed through the east portal to their final test ({@area area H7|0fd|x}). Dardew doesn't reveal what lies beyond any of the portals.

items.name: Portals
items.entry: Five portals in the arena lead to the following locations:

entries: {@b Portal A}. Portal A leads to {@area area H4|0ef|x}.
{@b Portal B}. Portal B leads to {@area area H3|0eb|x}.
{@b Portal C}. Portal C leads to {@area area H7|0fd|x}. The portal doesn't function until the characters have completed challenges in at least two other areas.
{@b Portal D}. Portal D leads to {@area area H5|0f4|x}.
{@b Portal E}. Portal E leads to {@area area H2|0e7|x}.
Each portal initially functions as a one-way door, preventing reentry until the characters have completed the challenge in the destination area.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Each time a character kills a Demobat, the audience throws 50 GP into this area.

entries.title: Dardew amuses a cultist of Demogorgon during a trivia round of Fiend Feud

entries.name: H2: Fiend Feud

entries: {@area Dardew|0d5|x} hovers impatiently over this room, which features two rusty, wrought-iron podiums that resemble corroded coffins. Five masked cultists stand behind one of the podiums, while the other is vacant.

"It's that time again!" Dardew announces to the devils above. "Are you ready for another game of Fiend Feud?" The audience cheers. "Contestants, take your places." Dardew clears his throat and gestures to the empty podium.

This challenge is called Fiend Feud, a trivia game of brains and bloodshed where two teams compete for fame, fortune—and their lives. The opposing team consists of five {@creature Cultist of Demogorgon|WttHC|Cultists of Demogorgon} who are {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward the characters. Dardew acts as host.
Once the characters take their places behind the podium, the game begins.

items.name: Playing Fiend Feud
items.entry: Fiend Feud is a trivia game with three rounds and a mostly arbitrary points system. The game's rules are as follows:

items.name: Trivia Questions
items.entry: Each round, Dardew asks the characters one question from the Fiend Feud Questions table, rerolling duplicates. These questions test player knowledge as much as character knowledge. The player characters are allowed to briefly deliberate before giving their response. If they answer the question correctly, their team receives 1 point.

items.name: Chance to Steal
items.entry: If the characters answer a question incorrectly, the opposing team has a chance answer the question, receiving 1 point if they answer it correctly. The cultists are well-versed in occult lore and answer any such questions correctly, but they know little about anything else and get those questions wrong. The cultists know the answers to questions 1, 4, and 6 in the Fiend Feud Questions table.

items.name: Bonus Round
items.entry: After three rounds of trivia, both teams can earn bonus points by killing members of the opposing team. Have everyone roll {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB}. For each opposing team member they slay, a team earns 1 point.

entries: The game ends when only one team remains.

{@comic If you really want to run a certain encounter, you can just have whichever portal the characters go through lead to that area. It's an old DM trick I like to call {@b "the invisible railroad."}}

entries.caption: Fiend Feud Questions
rows: What vile lich is missing one eye and one hand?
What creatures love brains but loathe zombies?
Which vampire lord rules over the land of Barovia?
Which demon lord is the self-styled Prince of Demons?
Which warrior severed the hand of a famous lich?
Which archdevil rules over all the Nine Hells?

entries: At the DM's discretion, a character can take the {@action Study|XPHB} action to make a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB} or {@skill Religion|XPHB}) check to know the answer to a question, learning the correct answer on a successful check.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Characters receive treasure as follows:

items.name: Correct Answers
items.entry: Whenever a character correctly answers a question, the audience throws 10 GP into this area.

items.name: Slaying Cultists
items.entry: Whenever a character slays a cultist, the audience throws 25 GP into this area.

items.name: Winning the Game
items.entry: If the characters win Fiend Feud, the audience showers them with 150 GP.

entries.name: H3: Demonic Incursion

entries: This fetid chamber holds a bubbling well of brownish sludge. In front of the well, a devil stands poised for battle. Glaive in hand, the devil sports a writhing beard of barbed, snakelike appendages.
"Fight well alongside me, maggots," it spits, "Or I'll stick you like the smelly flesh bags you are!" Just then, the well burps up six squealing demons, each more hideous than the last.
An unseen creature whispers in your ear. "Kill the demons, then kill this devil—make it look like an accident, and you'll be rewarded. You have my word!"

entries.title: A dretch bursts forth from a demonic well

items.name: DM Secret!
items.entry: Don't reveal the Imp Trickster yet. This monster is invisible.

entries: Six {@creature Dretch|WttHC|Dretches} erupt from the well. The {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} demons fight the characters and the {@creature Bearded Devil|WttHC}, which is initially {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} toward the party and fights alongside them. Once all six dretches have been slain, the challenge is complete, and the portal to {@area area H1|0e4|x} reopens.

A treacherous {@creature Imp Trickster|WttHC} with the {@condition Invisible|XPHB} condition watches the battle unfold. The imp loathes the bearded devil and wishes it dead but is {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} toward the characters. During the battle, the imp encourages characters to turn on the bearded devil when the last dretch falls.

entries.name: The Devil You Don't Know
entries: The bearded devil is an overbearing grunt who barks orders at the characters and scolds any who defy its commands. Whenever a character slays a demon, the bearded devil loudly takes credit for the kill.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Characters receive treasure as follows:

items: {@b Defeating the Bearded Devil}. If a character kills the bearded devil, the imp turns visible and gives them 200 GP.
{@b Defeating Dretches}. Each time a character kills a dretch, the audience throws 50 GP into this area.
{@b Defeating the Imp}. If a character kills the Imp Trickster, the bearded devil thanks the characters for eliminating "the spy" and gives them 10 GP.

entries.name: H4: Sanctuary of Yeenoghu

entries: Three mangy, hyenoid fiends conduct a ritual in this wicked sanctuary. In the center of the chamber, a giant, wicked-looking flail spins and stops at unpredictable intervals, violently swinging its three spiked heads.
Two of the creatures cackle maliciously as the third—completely hairless—chants, "Yeenoghu! Deliver us from this wretched game so we may spill blood in your name!"

Three {@creature Gnoll Warrior|WttHC|Gnoll Warriors} beseech the demon lord Yeenoghu for aid in this sanctuary. They are {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward all other creatures and rush them on sight.

These are the same gnolls from the Dungeon of Shadows (see "The Vanishing Gnome"). They have since died and made their way to the {@area Hellfire Dome|0e1|x}. If the characters fought them previously, the gnolls recognize them and greet them accordingly:
The gnolls visibly seethe with hatred. "You again?!" shouts the hairless gnoll. "Heretics! How dare you come here and interrupt our ritual a second time!"
The gnolls fight to the death (again).

entries.name: Flail
entries: The spinning flail is embedded in the ground between the gnolls. Each round on Initiative count 10 (losing Initiative ties), the flail's three heads crash to the ground. Each creature within 10 feet of the flail must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or take {@damage 3d6} Bludgeoning damage and have the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition. The flail doesn't harm the gnolls.
The flail has AC 18, HP 40, and Immunity to Poison and Psychic damage. If the flail is destroyed, it stops spinning, and the audience roars in jubilation.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Characters receive treasure as follows:

items.name: Defeating Gnolls
items.entry: Each time a character kills a gnoll, the audience throws 100 GP into this area.

items.name: Destroying the Flail
items.entry: If a character destroys the flail, the audience throws 200 GP into this area.

entries.name: H5: Infernal Court

entries: A judge with a nest of snakes for hair and wearing crimson robes presides over this infernal court. Two short podiums rest before the judge's bench, an imposing monument of black marble flanked by two snarling hounds; flames drip from the hounds' jaws. A lone imp perches atop one of the podiums. It snickers as you enter.

Nine petrified jurors with frightened expressions fill a juror's box to the north. The judge calls the court to order. "Order in the court!" the judge demands. "The accused have finally decided to join us—late and without representation. How do you plead?"

The judge is Yudith Duboix, a no-nonsense {@creature Medusa|WttHC}. Judge Deboix is {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward the characters, who have just entered their own trial. Two {@creature Hell Hound|WttHC|Hell Hounds} ferociously obey the judge's commands.

The trial proceeds through arraignment, statements, and sentencing, as detailed in the following sections. The characters can either represent themselves or allow the {@creature Imp Trickster|WttHC}, an unlicensed attorney, to provide them with bad-faith representation.

The jury is composed of adventurers petrified by Judge Deboix. If the characters try to fight the court instead, they might be similarly turned to stone, in which case {@area Dardew|0d5|x} can amend his contract (see "{@area Infernal Contract|0d8|x}" earlier in this adventure) to also remove the {@condition Petrified|XPHB} condition.

items.name: Arraignment
items.entry: After the characters' plea, Judge Duboix summarizes the charges against them, which might include but aren't limited to the following:

items.name: Arson
items.entry: A character is charged with arson if they've ever set anything on fire, including torches.

items.name: Failure to Appear
items.entry: A character is charged with failure to appear if their player has ever arrived late to a game session.

items.name: Murder
items.entry: A character is charged with murder if they've ever slain a creature in combat.

items.name: Thievery
items.entry: A character is charged with thievery if they've ever stolen property, including gold or items found in a dungeon or taken from the dead.

items.name: Trespassing
items.entry: A character is charged with trespassing if they've ever entered a location, including a dungeon, without permission.

entries: At your discretion, other offenses might be worthy of a charge in this kangaroo court.

entries.name: Statements
entries: The characters can confer and give a statement in their defense. A character can try to convince Judge Duboix of the party's innocence and make a {@dc 15} Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) check. On a successful check, Judge Duboix finds the party not guilty and dismisses the characters from the court. On a failed check (or if the characters chose to let the imp represent them), Judge Duboix rules against the party and moves to sentencing.
If the party is found not guilty, the challenge is considered complete, and the portal to {@area area H1|0e4|x} reopens.

entries.title: Judge Yudith Duboix, a stone-cold medusa judge, demands order in the infernal court

entries.name: Sentencing
entries: Judge Duboix's sentencing is harsh and swift. If the party is found guilty, the medusa sentences the characters to 1,000 years in prison. The judge then orders the hell hounds to escort the characters to the infernal prison ({@area area H6|0f9|x}) for detainment. If the characters refuse, the hell hounds leap into battle. Judge Duboix defends itself as necessary but otherwise abstains from combat. If both hounds are slain, Judge Duboix surrenders and overturns the previous verdict.
If the characters comply with sentencing and later return to this area, the courtroom is empty, and the portal to {@area area H1|0e4|x} reopens.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Characters receive treasure as follows:

items.name: Defeating Hell Hounds
items.entry: Each time a character kills a hound, the audience throws 200 GP into this area.

items.name: Defeating Judge Duboix
items.entry: If Judge Duboix dies, the audience throws 2,000 GP into this area.

items.name: Innocent Verdict
items.entry: If the party is found innocent, the audience throws 100 GP into this area.

entries.name: H6: Infernal Prison

entries: A devil covered in sharp barbs patrols this open-air cell block. The devil rattles its tail against the bars of the six cages, laughing cruelly at the prisoners. A key hangs around the devil's neck.

The warden of this prison is a masochistic {@creature Barbed Devil|WttHC} named Khaos, the Bringer of Pain. Khaos is {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward the characters. When they enter, the devil grunts and points them to the biggest cage (cage 1), attacking any who refuse to enter. Khaos then returns to marching up and down the block.

Khaos enjoys catching escaped prisoners and breaking their spirits and bodies. The devil doesn't confiscate inmates' equipment and pretends not to notice if they try to free themselves or one another. Khaos doesn't pursue runaways beyond this area.

entries.name: Cages
entries: Khaos wears the key to these six locked cages. As a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action, a character can try to pick a cage's lock using {@item Thieves' Tools|XPHB}, doing so with a successful {@dc 15} Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand|XPHB}) check. The check is made with {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} if the character is trying to pick the lock from inside the cage.

Alternatively, a character can try to goad Khaos into unlocking their cage. As an {@action Influence|XPHB} action, a character can taunt the barbed devil and make a {@dc 13} Charisma ({@skill Performance|XPHB}) check. On a successful check, Khaos unlocks the door, enters the cage, and strikes that character to teach them a lesson.
The cage's contents are as follows:

items: {@b Cage 1} contains only a bench chained to the wall.

{@b Cage 2} contains a {@creature Demogorgon Spawn|WttHC} captured on the battlefields of Avernus. The spawn is {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward all other creatures and tries to tear them limb from limb if freed from its cell.

{@b Cage 4} contains a human {@creature Cultist of Demogorgon|WttHC} who warns any who address her that the "Sibilant Beast" will consume them all. The {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} cultist fights any who enter her cell.

{@b Cage 5} contains an {@creature Imp Trickster|WttHC} playing a harmonica. The imp is {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} toward the characters but aids them in combat in this area if freed.

entries: If a character escapes their cage or frees one of the other imprisoned creatures, Khaos brays with malevolent laughter and fights the escapee.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Characters receive treasure as follows:

items.name: Defeating Khaos
items.entry: If a character kills Khaos, the audience throws 2,000 GP into this area.

items.name: Defeating the Demogorgon Spawn
items.entry: If a character kills the {@creature Demogorgon Spawn|WttHC}, the audience throws 150 GP into this area.

entries.name: H7: Demodragon Lair
entries: {@area Dardew|0d5|x} has tilted the odds in the characters' favor. When they enter this area, each character magically gains the benefits of finishing a Short Rest. Then, read or paraphrase the following text:
A river of molten lava flows through this scorched lair. Crumbling rubble, dried viscera, and cracked bones litter the ground, a barren landscape marred by past battles.

The earth trembles as a massive abomination with a sickly gray hide, razor-sharp claws, and two faceless heads rises from a mound of glittering treasure. It stretches its wide, leathery wings and unfurls its heads to reveal two gaping maws of toothed, fleshy petals. The behemoth bellows two bone-chilling roars.
Roll initiative!

The final challenge in the Hellfire Games is the {@creature Demodragon|WttHC}, an abomination that has slaughtered scores of contestants. The Demodragon is {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward the characters and fights to the death.

items.name: Lava
items.entry: Rivers of lava flow throughout this area, as shown on the map. A creature that enters the lava for the first time on a turn or starts its turn in the lava takes {@damage 6d10} fire damage.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The Demodragon's hoard contains the following: an {@item Adamantine Breastplate|XDMG|Adamantine Armor (Breastplate)}, a {@item Spiked Shield|WttHC}, a {@item Potion of Healing|XDMG}, and 2,420 GP.

entries.title: The Demodragon rouses from its slumber to devour foolhardy contestants

entries.name: Conclusion
entries: The Hellfire Games conclude when the characters vanquish the Demodragon or die trying. If the characters defeat the Demodragon, read or paraphrase the following text:
With an earthshaking crash, the Demodragon collapses dead before you. The crowd goes wild.
Dardew soars overhead. "Wow! What a show!" he crows. "Friends and fiends, please join me in welcoming our latest Hellfire champions!"
He flies toward you and says quietly, "Adventurers, now would be a great time to take a bow. You've earned it."
In addition to the treasure they collected in the Hellfire Dome, the characters earn the following rewards for winning the Hellfire Games:

items.name: Hellfire Club Membership
items.entry: {@area Dardew|0d5|x} invites characters to join the Hellfire Club. If they accept his invitation, they each receive a pendant worth 50 GP. The pendant depicts the face of a red devil flanked by a flail and flaming sword.

items.name: Hellfire Hall of Fame
items.entry: The characters are inducted into the Hellfire Hall of Fame. Their names are recorded forever in the annals of infernal history alongside other legendary heroes and villains.

items.name: Voiding the Infernal Contract
items.entry: If any character entered into an infernal contract with Dardew (see "{@area Infernal Contract|0d8|x}" earlier in this adventure), Dardew voids the contract.

entries: When the characters are ready to leave the Nine Hells, Dardew magically returns them to Greyhawkins. Before he departs, Dardew thanks them for the magnificent performance.
{@comic {@b Congratulations.}}
{@comic Hellfire is officially in your hands.}

{@comic You should take a bow, too. Being a DM can feel overwhelming sometimes, but know this: {@b You're not alone}. I promise. If you ever need a pep talk, I'm just a phone call away. Save me a seat at your table. I'll be back to see what you've done with the place.}

entries: Dungeons & Dragons is a cooperative game in which players create exciting fantasy stories guided by a Dungeon Master, or DM.
Imagination and chance determine the fate of the players' characters.

entries.name: Playing a Character
entries: Choose a character. Team up. Venture forth.

entries.name: Being the Dungeon Master
entries: Run the {@variantrule Adventure|XPHB}. Guide the story. Adjudicate the rules.

entries.name: A Note From Eddie
entries: Allow me to let you in on a little secret: nobody knows all the rules by heart. I sure as hell don't. That's what these guides are for. The rules are there to help everyone at the table tell a story. If you ever feel like the rules are getting in the way of that, remember the most important rule of all: have fun.
At the end of the day, that's all that matters.
